paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO,BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO,MARGARET, URSULA enter along with other partygoers. They're all wearing masks.
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
BENEDICK
BALTHASAR
DON JOHN
BORACHIO
MARGARET
URSULA

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
My lady, will you have a dance with me?

paragraphs.original: They begin to dance
paragraphs.translated: They begin to dance.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say nothing, I am
yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
As long as you move gracefully, look handsome, and say nothing, I'm yours for the dance. And I'll even linger after I've gone.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
With me in your company?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Will I be with you then?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
I may say so when I please.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Perhaps, if I decide to let you.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
And when please you to say so?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
And when will that be?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
When I like your favor, for God defend the lute should be
like the case!
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
When I like the way you look, for God forbid your face be as ugly as your mask!

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
My mask is like the roof of the poor
Philemon's humble cottage; underneath the mask, I am as magnificent as the glorious god Jove.
Philemon's

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Why, then, your visor should be thatched.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Well, then, since Philemon's roof was thatched with straw, your mask should have a beard.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Speak low if you speak love.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
If you wish to speak of love, speak more softly.

paragraphs.original:
They move aside. BALTHASAR andMARGARET move forward
BALTHASAR
MARGARET
paragraphs.translated:
They move aside. BALTHASAR andMARGARET move forward.
BALTHASAR
MARGARET

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
Well, I would you did like me.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
Well, I wish you liked me.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
So would not I for your own sake, for I have many ill qualities.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
I'm glad I don't, for your sake. I have many awful qualities.

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
Which is one?
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
Tell me one.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
I say my prayers aloud.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
I say my prayers out loud.

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
I love you the better; the hearers may cry "Amen."
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
That makes me love you even more. Everyone who hears you can shout, "Amen."

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
God match me with a good dancer!
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
God give me a good dance partner!

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
Amen.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
Amen. That would be me.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done!
Answer, clerk.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
And God take him away from me when we're finished dancing! Go ahead - say "Amen."

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
No more words. The clerk is answered.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
No more talking. I've got my answer.

paragraphs.original:
They move aside. URSULA andANTONIO move forward.
URSULA
ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated:
They move aside. URSULA andANTONIO move forward.
URSULA
ANTONIO

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
I know you well enough. You are Signor Antonio.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
I know who you are; you are Signior Antonio.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
At a word, I am not.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
No, really, I'm not.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
I know you by the waggling of your head.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
I can tell by the way you waggle your head.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
To tell you true, I counterfeit him.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Really, I'm only pretending to be him.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
You could never do him so ill-well unless you were the very
man. Here's his dry hand up and down. You are he, you are
he.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
You could only imitate his imperfections so well if you were the man himself. Look, you've got his wrinkled hands. You are Antonio, you are he.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
At a word, I am not.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
In short, I'm not.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your
excellent wit? Can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum, you are
he. Graces will appear, and there's an end.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Come on, do you think I can't recognize you by your excellent wit? Can a good thing hide itself? Be quiet, you are Antonio. A man's virtues will always show themselves, and that's the end of that.

paragraphs.original:
They move aside. BENEDICK andBEATRICE move forward.
BENEDICK
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
They move aside. BENEDICK andBEATRICE move forward.
BENEDICK
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Will you not tell me who told you so?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Won't you tell me who told you that?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
No, you shall pardon me.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
No, you'll have to excuse me.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Nor will you not tell me who you are?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
And you won't tell me who you are?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Not now.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Not now.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
That I was disdainful and that I had my good wit out of The
Hundred Merry Tales! Well this was Signor Benedick that
said so.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Who said that I was disdainful, and that I got all my best lines out of a bad joke book?! Well, it must have been Signior Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
What's he?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Who's that?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I am sure you know him well enough.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I'm sure you know him.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Not I, believe me.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
No I don't, believe me.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Did he never make you laugh?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
What, he never made you laugh?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
I pray you, what is he?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Please tell me, who is this man?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Why, he is the Prince's jester, a very dull fool, only his gift
is in devising impossible slanders. None but libertines
delight in him, and the commendation is not in his wit but
in his villainy, for he both pleases men and angers them,
and then they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in
the fleet. I would he had boarded me.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Why, he's the Prince's fool, and a very dull fool at that. His only talent is his capacity to come up with unbelievable slanders. Only the most immoral people enjoy his company, and they like him not for his wit but his outrageousness. He manages to both please and anger people; they laugh at him and then beat him up. I'm sure he's out there dancing. I could have sworn he trampled on me.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
When I meet this gentleman, I'll tell him what you've said.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Do, do. He'll but break a comparison or two on me, which,
peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into
melancholy, and then there's a partridge wing saved, for the
fool will eat no supper that night.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Oh, please do. He'll say a few nasty things about me, and if nobody listens to him or laughs, he'll be thrown into a funk. And that will save a partridge wing from being eaten, because he'll be too miserable for dinner.

paragraphs.original: Music for the dance
paragraphs.translated: Music for the dance begins.

paragraphs.original: We must follow the leaders.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, we have to follow the leaders of the dance.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
In every good thing.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
In every good thing they do.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next
turning.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
No, if they try to lead us to harm, I will leave the dance floor at the next song.

paragraphs.original:
Dance, then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
DON JOHN
BORACHIO
CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated:
There is a dance. Everyone exits except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, andCLAUDIO.
DON JOHN
BORACHIO
CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
(to BORACHIO) Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and
(to
)
hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it. The
ladies follow her, and but one visor remains.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
(to BORACHIO) My brother just wooed Hero and now has taken her father inside to tell him his feelings. The ladies have followed Hero, but one masked man remains.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
And that is Claudio. I know him by his bearing.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
That's Claudio. I can tell by the way he carries himself.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
(to CLAUDIO) Are not you Signor Benedick?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
(to CLAUDIO) Aren't you Signior Benedick?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
You know me well. I am he.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
You know me too well. I am Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Signor, you are very near my brother in his love. He is
enamored on Hero. I pray you, dissuade him from her. She
is no equal for his birth. You may do the part of an honest
man in it.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
Sir, my brother is very fond of you. He is in love with Hero. Please make him change his mind. She doesn't have the proper rank to marry the Prince. You would be doing a good service.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
How know you he loves her?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
How do you know he loves her?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
I heard him swear his affection.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
I heard him swear he did.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
I did too, and he also swore he would marry her tonight.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Come, let us to the banquet.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
Come on, let's get to the banquet.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt DON JOHN andBORACHIO
DON JOHN
BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN andBORACHIO exit.
DON JOHN
BORACHIO

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(unmasking)
(unmasking)
Thus answer I in the name of Benedick,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
'Tis certain so, the Prince woos for himself.
Friendship is constant in all other things
Save in the office and affairs of love.
Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.
Let every eye nogetiate for itself
And trust no agent, for beauty is a witch
Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
This is an accident of hourly proof,
Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(taking off his mask)
(taking off his mask)
Though I said my name was Benedick, I heard this news with Claudio's ears. Of course the Prince wants Hero for himself. Friendship is enduring except when love is involved. Therefore, all lovers should speak for themselves. They should look for themselves, without asking someone else to get involved in their affairs. Beauty is a witch whose spells can turn loyalty into passion. This happens a lot, but it didn't occur to me that it would happen to me. Goodbye then, Hero.

paragraphs.original:
Enter BENEDICK
BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK enters.
BENEDICK

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Count Claudio?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Claudio?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Yea, the same.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Yes, that's me.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Come, will you go with me?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Will you come with me?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Whither?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Where?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Even to the next willow, about your own business, county.
What fashion will you wear the garland of? About your
neck like an usurer's chain? Or under your arm like a
lieutenant's scarf? You must wear it one way, for the Prince
hath gat your Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Right over to that
willow tree to see about your business. How do you want to wear your garland of willow leaves? Around your neck, like a moneylender's gold chain, or under your arm, like a lieutenant's sash? You have to wear it somehow, because the Prince has gotten your Hero.
willow tree

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I wish him joy of her.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I hope he enjoys her.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Why, that's spoken like an honest drover; so they sell
bullocks. But did you think the Prince would have served
you thus?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
You sound like a cattle dealer: that's the way they sell bulls. But do you really think the Prince would treat you that way?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I pray you, leave me.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Please, leave me alone.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Ho, now you strike like the blind man. 'Twas the boy that
stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Look at you, thrashing about like a blind man. A boy robbed you, but you'll beat up the post instead.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
If it will not be, I'll leave you.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
If you won't leave, then I'll leave.
I'll

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Alas, poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into sedges. But that
my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me! The
Prince's fool! Ha, it may be I go under that title because I am
merry. Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong. I am not so
reputed! It is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice
that puts the world into her person and so gives me out.
Well, I'll be revenged as I may.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Oh, the poor bird. Now he'll hide himself in the bushes. But how strange that Beatrice should seem to know who I was and yet not know at the same time. "The Prince's fool"! Maybe they call me that because I am cheerful. Yes, but I am insulting myself by thinking this way. I don't have that kind of reputation! Beatrice's mean, sarcastic nature makes her believe that the entire world shares her opinions; that's why she describes me this way. Well, I'll get my revenge.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON PEDRO
DON PEDRO
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO enters.
DON PEDRO

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Now, Signior, where's the Count? Did you see him?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Now, sir, where is Claudio? Did you see him?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame. I
found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren. I told
him, and I think I told him true, that your Grace had got the
goodwill of this young lady, and I offered him my company
to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as being
forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be
whipped.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Yes, my lord, I played the part of a gossip and brought him the news. I found him here,
as sad as a rabbit in a burrow. I told him - and I think I was telling the truth - that you had won the lady's heart. I offered to accompany him to the willow tree, where he could either make a garland - fit to be worn by an abandoned lover - or gather sticks into a bundle, ready for his beating.
as sad as a rabbit in a burrow

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
To be whipped? What's his fault?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Beating? Why, what did he do?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed
with finding a birds' nest, shows it his companion, and he
steals it.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
He was like a schoolboy who finds a bird's nest and happily shows it to his friend, who then steals it from him.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The transgression
is in the stealer.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What, is trusting a friend such a crime? The criminal is the one who stole the nest.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the
garland too, for the garland he might have worn himself
and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take
it, have stolen his birds' nest.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
It might have been appropriate to make both the rod and the garland. He could have worn the garland himself and beaten you with the rod, since you - as I understand it - have stolen his bird's nest.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
I will but teach them to sing and restore them to the owner.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I only want to teach the baby birds to sing; then I will return the nest to its rightful owner.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you say
honestly.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
We'll wait and see; if the chicks follow your lead - if Hero is ready to love Claudio - then we'll know you're telling the truth.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you. The gentleman
that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Lady Beatrice is angry with you. The gentleman she danced with told her you insulted her.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
O, she misused me past the endurance of a block! An oak
but with one green leaf on it would have answered her. My
very visor began to assume life and scold with her. She told
me, not thinking I had been myself, that I was the Prince's
jester, that I was duller than a great thaw, huddling jest
upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me that I
stood like a man at a mark with a whole army shooting at
me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs. If her
breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no
living near her; she would infect to the north star. I would
not marry her, though she were endowed with all that
Adam had left him before he transgressed. She would have
made Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club
to make the fire, too. Come, talk not of her. You shall find
her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God some
scholar would conjure her, for certainly, while she is here,
a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary, and people
sin upon purpose because they would go thither. So indeed
all disquiet, horror and perturbation follows her.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Not even a block of wood could handle her abuses! An oak tree barely clinging to life would have revived itself to fight her. Even my mask seemed to come to life in order to argue with her. She told me - not realizing it was me - that I was the Prince's jester and as dull as mud. She hurled mocking insults at me with such incredible speed that all I could do was stand there, paralyzed. She speaks daggers, and every word stabs. If her breath were as terrible as her words, she would kill every living thing from here to the furthest star. I wouldn't marry her, even if she were as blessed as paradise. If she were married to the great hero Hercules, she would have humiliated him with chores around the house and ordered him to chop up his famous club for firewood. Please, don't mention her. She's as wicked as
Ate, just disguised in pretty clothes. I wish to God that some wise man would conjure her away, because as long as she lives on earth, our lives are filled with turmoil. It's quieter in hell, where people, sinning on purpose, are eager to be sent just to get away from her. So chaos, horror, and sorrow follow her wherever she goes.
Ate

paragraphs.original:
Enter CLAUDIO,BEATRICE, HERO, andLEONATO
CLAUDIO
BEATRICE
HERO
LEONATO
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO, BEATRICE,HERO, and LEONATO enter.
CLAUDIO
BEATRICE
HERO
LEONATO

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Look, here she comes.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Look, here she comes.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Will your grace command me any service to the world's
end? I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes
that you can devise to send me on. I will fetch you a
toothpicker now from the furthest inch of Asia, bring you
the length of Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the
great Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pygmies,
rather than hold three words' conference with this harpy.
You have no employment for me?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Your highness, could you send me on a mission to the ends of the earth? I'll go to the Antipodes for any little errand you can think of. I'll fetch you a toothpick from the
farthest reaches of Asia, or find out Prester John's shoe size, or snatch a hair from Kublai Khan's beard, or deliver any message you wish to relay to the Pygmies - anything rather than exchange three words with this awful, screeching woman. Isn't there something you want from me?
farthest reaches of Asia

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
None but to desire your good company.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Nothing but your good company.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
O God, sir, here's a dish I love not. I cannot endure my
Lady Tongue!
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Oh, God, sir, here comes a dish I hate. I can't stand tongue.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
(to BEATRICE) Come, lady, come, you have lost the heart of
(to
)
Signior Benedick.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
(to BEATRICE) Lady, you have lost Signior Benedick's heart.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gave him use for
it, a double heart for his single one. Marry, once before he
won it of me with false dice. Therefore your Grace may well
say I have lost it.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
It's true, my lord. He lent it to me once, and I paid him back with interest: a double heart for his single one. Really, he won it from me once before in a dishonest game of dice. So I suppose your grace can truly say that I have lost it.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
You've humiliated him, lady: you've put him down.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove
the mother of fools. I have brought Count Claudio, whom
you sent me to seek.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
And I hope that he won't
put me down or I'm sure to have fools for children.I've brought Claudio, who you sent me to find.
put me down

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Why, how now, Count, wherefore are you sad?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Why, what's wrong, count? Why are you so sad?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Not sad, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I'm not sad, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
How then, sick?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What then, sick?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Neither, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I'm neither, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well, but
civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous
complexion.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
The count is neither sad nor sick nor cheerful nor well - he's just civil, as Seville as an orange, with the same jealous-yellow complexion.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true, though, I'll be
sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false. - Here, Claudio, I
have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won. I have broke
with her father and his goodwill obtained. Name the day of
marriage, and God give thee joy.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Truly, lady, I think your description is correct, though I swear he has no reason to look like that. Here, Claudio, I've wooed Hero for you, and she's agreed to marry you. I've told her father, and he's given his permission. Tell us when you wish to get married, and may God give you joy.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes.
His grace hath made the match, and all grace say "Amen"
to it.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Claudio, take my daughter, and, with her, take my fortunes. The Prince has made the match, and may God bless it.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Speak, Count, 'tis your cue.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Speak, Claudio, that's your cue.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Silence is the perfectest herald of joy. I were but little happy
if I could say how much. - Lady, as you are mine, I am
yours. I give away myself for you and dote upon the
exchange.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Complete joy makes one speechless; if I were only a little happy, then I could say exactly how much. Lady, you are mine and I am yours. For you, I give myself away and I'm ecstatic about the exchange.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Speak, cousin, or if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss
and let not him speak neither.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Say something, cousin. Or, if you can't say anything, stop his mouth with a kiss and don't let him speak, either.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Truly, lady, you have a merry heart.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Yea, my lord. I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side
of care. My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Yes, my lord. I thank my heart - the poor fool - for it keeps away from seriousness. Look, my cousin is whispering to Claudio that she loves him.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
And so she doth, cousin.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Why, you're absolutely right, cousin.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Good Lord for alliance! Thus goes everyone to the world
but I, and I am sunburnt. I may sit in a corner and cry,
"Heigh-ho for a husband!"
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Thank the lord for alliances! So everyone goes off into the world except me, who stays in because I'm sunburned. I should sit in the corner and sing that song, "Heigh-Ho for a Husband!"

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Lady Beatrice, I'll get you a husband.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I would rather have one of your father's getting. Hath your
grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent
husbands, if a maid could come by them.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I'd rather get a husband from your father. Don't you have any brothers like you? Your father's sons would make excellent husbands, if only a girl could catch one for herself.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Will you have me, lady?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Will you take me, my lady?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days.
Your Grace is too costly to wear every day. But I beseech
your Grace pardon me. I was born to speak all mirth and no
matter.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
No, my lord, unless I could have another husband for the work week. You are too expensive to wear every day. But please, forgive me, your highness. I was born to speak cleverly, not seriously.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best
becomes you, for out o' question you were born in a merry
hour.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I'd be more offended if you were silent, for being lively and cheerful suits you best. Surely, you must have been born at a happy time.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
No, sure, my lord, my mother cried, but then there was a
star danced, and under that was I born. - Cousins, God
give you joy!
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Actually, my lord, my mother cried when she was giving birth to me. But then a star danced in the sky, and that's the moment I was born. - Kinsmen, I'm off.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Niece, will you take care of those things I mentioned?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I cry you mercy, uncle. - By your Grace's pardon.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Oh, yes, I'm sorry, uncle. - If you'll excuse me, your grace.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I swear, she's a very good-natured lady.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
There's little of the melancholy element in her, my lord. She
is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, for
I have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamed of
unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
There's very little about her that's gloomy, my lord. She's only sad when she sleeps - and not even then. Hero told me that Beatrice has often had dreams about being unhappy, and managed to wake herself from them by laughing.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
She can't stand to hear about getting a husband.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Oh, by no means. She mocks all her wooers out of suit.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
No, not at all. She mocks all her suitors so severely that they drop the suit.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
She were an excellent wife for Benedict.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
She would make a good wife for Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they
would talk themselves mad.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Oh, Lord, if they were married, they'd drive themselves crazy within a week.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Count Claudio, when do you plan to go to church and be married?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Tomorrow, my lord. Time goes on crutches till love have all
his rites.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Tomorrow, my lord. Time will move as slowly as an old man until our love receives its proper ceremony.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just
sevennight, and a time too brief, too, to have all things
answer my mind.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Wait till Monday, my dear son, which is only a week away. Even that is too short a time to plan things the way I would like.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
(to CLAUDIO) Come, you shake the head at so long a
(to
)
breathing, but I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go
dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of Hercules'
labors, which is to bring Signor Benedick and the Lady
Beatrice into a mountain of affection, th' one with th' other.
I would fain have it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion
it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall
give you direction.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
(to CLAUDIO) Oh, don't look so frustrated at having to wait so long. I promise you, Claudio, the time will go by quickly. While we're waiting for the wedding, I'm going to take on an impossible task: to make Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice fall in love with each other. I aim to see them matched, and with all of your help, I'm sure we can make it happen.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights'
watchings.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
My lord, I will help you, even if it means I have to stay awake for ten nights straight.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
And I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Me too, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
And you too, gentle Hero?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
And you, sweet Hero?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a
good husband.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
I'll do any decent thing, my lord, to help my cousin get a good husband.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
And Benedick is not the unhopefulest husband that I know.
Thus far can I praise him: he is of a noble strain, of approved
valor, and confirmed honesty. I will teach you how to humor
your cousin that she shall fall in love with Benedick. - And
I, with your two helps, will so practice on Benedick
that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he
shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this, Cupid is no
longer an archer; his glory shall be ours, for we are the only
love gods. Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
And Benedick is not the worst husband I can think of. This much I can say about him: he is well-born, has proven his bravery in battle, and has established his good character. Hero, I'll show you how to influence your cousin so she falls in love with Benedick. We men will trick Benedick so that, despite his quick wit and his queasiness about marriage, he will fall in love with her. If we can do this, then we will steal Cupid's glory. We will be the supreme love gods! Come inside with me, and I will tell you my plan.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON JOHN andBORACHIO
DON JOHN
BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated:
Enter DON JOHN andBORACHIO
DON JOHN
BORACHIO

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
It is so. The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of
Leonato.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
It's arranged. The Count Claudio will marry Leonato's daughter.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Yea, my lord, but I can cross it.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Yes, my lord, but I can spoil it.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable to
me. I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes
athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine. How canst
thou cross this marriage?
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
Any obstacle or barrier to Claudio's happiness will be like medicine to me. I hate him so much it makes me sick, and whoever can ruin his happiness will make me happy. How will you wreck this marriage?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty
shall appear in me.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
I can only do it by lying, my lord, but I can do it so secretly that no one will suspect me.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Show me briefly how.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
Quickly, tell me how.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in
the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
I think it was a year ago that I told you how much Margaret, Hero's servant woman, likes me.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
I remember.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
I remember.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint her
to look out at her lady's chamber window.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
I can arrange it so that at some indecent hour of the night, she looks out Hero's bedroom window.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
How will that kill this marriage?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to the
Prince your brother. Spare not to tell him that he hath
wronged his honor in marrying the renowned Claudio,
whose estimation do you mightily hold up, to a
contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
That part is up to you. Go to the Prince, your brother, and tell him that he has done a terrible thing by matching the renowned Claudio - whom you greatly admire - with such a tainted whore as Hero.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
What proof shall I make of that?
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
What will be my evidence?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo
Hero, and kill Leonato. Look you for any other issue?
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Evidence enough to deceive the Prince, anger Claudio, ruin Hero, and kill Leonato. Is there anything else you wish?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Only to despite them, I will endeavor anything.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
That's all I want, and I'll do anything to accomplish it.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Go then, find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the
Count Claudio alone. Tell them that you know that Hero
loves me. Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and
Claudio, as in love of your brother's honor, who hath made
this match, and his friend's reputation, who is thus like to
be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have
discovered thus. They will scarcely believe this without
trial. Offer them instances, which shall bear no less
likelihood than to see me at her chamber window, hear me
call Margaret "Hero," hear Margaret term me "Claudio,"
and bring them to see this the very night before the
intended wedding, for in the meantime I will so fashion the
matter that Hero shall be absent, and there shall appear
such seeming truth of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall
be called assurance and all the preparation overthrown.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Find a time to speak with Don Pedro and Claudio alone. Tell them you know that Hero loves me. Pretend to be very concerned about both the Prince, who has compromised his honor by making the match, and Claudio, whose reputation will be ruined by this woman who's pretending to be a virgin. Of course, they won't believe you without proof. Tell them you've seen the two of us at Hero's bedroom window, and then bring them to see for themselves on the night before the wedding. I'll arrange it so that Hero is away for the night, so what they'll actually see is Margaret and me at the window, calling each other "Hero" and
"Claudio." It'll be such blatant evidence of Hero's disloyalty that Claudio's jealousy will quickly turn to certainty, and the wedding will be instantly called off.
"Claudio."

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in
practice. Be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a
thousand ducats.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
Make the arrangements, and I'll do it. Do this carefully, and I will reward you with a thousand gold coins.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not
shame me.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
If you make the accusation convincingly, then my cunning won't fail me.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
I will presently go learn their day of marriage.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
I'll go now to find out the date of the wedding.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter BENEDICK
BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK enters.
BENEDICK

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Boy!
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Boy!

paragraphs.original:
Enter BOY
BOY
paragraphs.translated:
A BOY enters.
BOY

paragraphs.original:
BOY
Signior?
paragraphs.translated:
BOY
Yes Signior?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
In my chamber window lies a book. Bring it hither to me in
the orchard.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
In my bedroom window there is a book. Go get it and bring it to me here in the orchard.

paragraphs.original:
BOY
I am here already, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
BOY
I'm already here, sir.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
I know that, but I would have thee hence and here again.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I see that you are here, but I'd like you to go there and then come back again.

paragraphs.original:
Exit BOY
BOY
paragraphs.translated:
The BOY exits.
BOY

paragraphs.original:
I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another
man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviors to love, will,
after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others,
become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love - 
and such a man is Claudio. I have known when there was no
music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he
rather hear the tabor and the pipe. I have known when he
would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor, and
now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new
doublet. He was wont to speak plain and to the purpose,
like an honest man and a soldier, and now is he turned
orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet, just
so many strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with
these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not.
paragraphs.translated: I'm amazed that a man, after watching romance turn another man into a fool and laughing at that man, can turn right around and become the thing he's scorned. That's the kind of man Claudio is. I knew him when he listened to nothing but the military drum and fife; now he would rather hear the sweet and refined music of the tabor and pipe. I knew him when he would've walked ten miles to see a well-crafted suit of armor; now he spends ten nights awake in his room designing himself a fancy new jacket. He used to speak plainly and to the point, like an honorable man and soldier; now his speech is elaborate and flowery. His words are like a miraculous banquet, full of strange new dishes. Will I be changed like that, and see the world through a lover's eyes? I'm not sure, but I don't think so.

paragraphs.original:
I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster,
but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me,
he shall never make me such a fool. One woman is fair, yet
I am well; another is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous,
yet I am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one
woman shall not come in my grace. Rich she shall be, that's
certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen
her; fair, or I'll ever look on her; mild, or come not near
me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse, an
excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what color it
please God. Ha! The Prince and Monsieur Love! I will hide
me in the arbor.
paragraphs.translated: I can't promise that love won't transform me, but I can promise you this: until I truly fall in love, a woman will never make me act like such a fool. A beautiful woman comes along, but I'm unmoved. A wise woman turns up, but I'm unmoved. A virtuous woman appears, but I'm unmoved. I refuse to fall in love until all three qualities unite in a single woman. She must be rich, certainly, and smart, or I'll have nothing to do with her. She has to be virtuous, or I'll never bid on her; beautiful, or I won't bother to look at her. Mild-mannered, or else she should stay away from me. Noble, or I won't have her even if she's an angel. She must be well spoken, an excellent musician, and her hair should be - well, I suppose the color doesn't matter. Ha! Look, it's the Prince and Mr. Love. I'll hide in the arbor.

paragraphs.original: He hides
paragraphs.translated: He hides.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, and LEONATO, andBALTHASAR with music
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
LEONATO
BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO enter. BALTHASAR enters with music.
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
LEONATO
BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Come, shall we hear this music?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Well, should we hear some music?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,
As hushed on purpose to grace harmony!
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Yes, my lord. Listen to how quiet the evening is, as if it's purposefully setting the stage for a song.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
(aside to CLAUDIO)
(aside to
)
See you where Benedick hath hid himself?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
(speaking so that only CLAUDIOcan hear) Do you see where Benedick is hiding?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(aside to DON PEDRO)
(aside to
)
O, very well, my lord. The music ended,
We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(speaking so that only DON PEDROcan hear) Yes, very well, my lord. Once the music has ended, we'll give him more than he bargained for.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Come on, Balthasar, let's hear that song again.

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice
To slander music anymore than once.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
Oh, my good lord, don't make me insult music again with my awful singing.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
It is the witness still of excellency
To put a strange face on his own perfection.
I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
You can tell an artist is excellent when he denies his own perfection. Please, sing for us; don't make me woo you anymore!

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
Because you talk of wooing, I will sing,
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he woos,
Yet will he swear he loves.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
Since you put it that way, I'll sing. You're like a suitor who courts a woman insincerely, swearing that he loves her even though he really doesn't find her worthy.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Nay, pray thee, come,
Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Come on, please sing. If you'd like to continue this discussion, at least do so with music.

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
Note this before my notes:
There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
Just know this before I begin: I can't play a single note that's worthy of note.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks!
Note notes, forsooth, and nothing.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Listen to him speaking in quarter notes! Get on with your note-playing now.

paragraphs.original: Music plays
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
(aside) Now, divine air! Now is his soul ravished. Is it not
(aside)
strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out of men's
bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when all's done.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
(to himself) That music must be divine, because their souls have been captivated. Isn't it strange that strings made of sheep's guts are capable of drawing men's souls out of their bodies? Well, I'd rather listen to a plain old hunting horn than this music, when all is said and done.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
By my troth, a good song.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
That's a good song.

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
And an ill singer, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
And a bad singer, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Ha, no, no, faith, thou sing'st well enough for a shift.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Ha! No, no, really, your voice is good enough in a pinch.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
(aside) An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,
(aside)
they would have hanged him. And I pray God his bad voice
bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the night raven,
come what plague could have come after it.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
(to himself) If a dog had howled like that, I would have hung it. I hope his horrible singing doesn't have any ill effects. I would've rather listened to the night raven screech, even if the bird's noise does give me the plague, as they say it will.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee, get us
some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it
at the Lady Hero's chamber window
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Yes, do you hear me, Balthasar? Please, get some excellent music, because tomorrow we want to serenade Lady Hero at her bedroom window.

paragraphs.original:
BALTHASAR
The best I can, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR
I'll do the best I can, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Do so. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Please do. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original:
Exit BALTHASAR
BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated:
BALTHASAR exits.
BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original:
Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of today,
that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick?
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Leonato. What was it that you told me today - that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Oh, ay. (aside to DON PEDRO) Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl
(aside to
)
sits. - I did never think that lady would have loved any
man.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Oh yes. (speaking so that only DON PEDRO can hear) Go on, keep walking: our prey is in sight. - I never thought that woman would love any man.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
No, nor I neither, but most wonderful that she should so
dote on Signor Benedick, whom she hath in all outward
behaviors seemed ever to abhor.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I didn't, either. But how wonderful that she should be so fond of Signior Benedick, whom she has always appeared to hate.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
(aside) Is 't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
(to himself) Is it possible? Is that the way the wind is blowing?
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it, but
that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the
infinite of thought.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Really, my lord, I don't know what to make of it, but she loves him with such a passion that it's past all understanding.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
May be she doth but counterfeit.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Maybe she's just pretending.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Faith, like enough.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Yes, that's quite likely.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
O God! Counterfeit? There was never counterfeit of
passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Oh God! Pretending? No one has ever faked passion as skillfully as this, then.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Why, what effects of passion shows she?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Why, what symptoms of love does she exhibit?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(aside to LEONATO) Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.
(aside to
)
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(speaking so that only LEONATOcan hear) Bait the hook well; this fish is going to bite.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
What effects, my lord? She will sit you - you heard my
daughter tell you how.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
What symptoms, my lord? She will have a seat - you heard my daughter tell you how.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
She did indeed.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Yes, she did tell us.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
How, how I pray you? You amaze me. I would have thought
her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Please, please tell me! This is amazing. I would have thought she was invincible against any assault of love.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against
Benedick.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I would have sworn that, too, my lord, especially against Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
(aside) I should think this a gull but that the white-bearded
(aside)
fellow speaks it. Knavery cannot, sure, hide himself in such
reverence.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
(to himself) I would take this as a joke if the old man weren't saying it. Mischief surely can't be hiding in such a respectable man.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(aside to DON PEDRO) He hath ta'en th' infection. Hold it up.
(aside to
)
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(speaking so that only DON PEDROcan hear) We've infected him! Keep it up.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Has she told Benedick how she feels?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
No, and swears she never will. That's her torment.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
No, and she swears she never will. That's what's driving her crazy.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
'Tis true indeed, so your daughter says. "Shall I," says she,
"that have so oft encountered him with scorn, write to him
that I love him?"
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
It's true, Hero says so. Beatrice asks, "Does it make any sense to write and tell him I love him when I have always treated him with scorn?"

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
This says she now when she is beginning to write to him, for
she'll be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her
smock till she have writ a sheet of paper. My daughter tells
us all.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
She says this as she begins to write the letter. She'll be getting up twenty times in a night, sitting there in her slip until she's written a page. My daughter told me everything.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest
your daughter told.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Now that you speak of paper, I remember a funny story of Hero's.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Oh, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she found
"Benedick" and "Beatrice" between the sheet?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Oh, you mean when Beatrice writes a letter and Hero sees that it has "Benedick" and "Beatrice" written all over it?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
That.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Yes, that's the one.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at
herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that
she knew would flout her. "I measure him," says she, "by
my own spirit, for I should flout him if he writ to me, yea,
though I love him, I should."
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Oh, she tears that letter into a thousand small pieces and berates herself for being so forward as to write a letter to a man she knows would mock her. "I compare him," she says, "to myself, and I know that I would mock him if he wrote me such a letter. Yes, even though I love him, I would mock him."

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her
heart, tears her hair, prays, curses: "O sweet Benedick! God
give me patience!"
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Then she falls down to her knees, weeps, sobs, beats her breast, tears her hair, prays, and curses: "Oh sweet Benedick! God give me patience!"

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
She doth indeed, my daughter says so, and the ecstasy hath
so much overborne her that my daughter is sometime
afeared
she will do a desperate outrage to herself. It is very true.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
She did indeed, my daughter says so. She worries that Beatrice is so overwrought that she might do herself harm someday. It's true.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she
will not discover it.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
If she won't tell Benedick, someone else should.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
To what end? He would make but a sport of it and torment
the poor lady worse.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
And what would that accomplish? He'll just turn it into a joke and torment the poor woman even more.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an
excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is
virtuous.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
If he did that, it would be a charitable deed to hang him. She's an excellent, sweet woman, and there's no doubt that she is virtuous.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
And she is exceeding wise.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
And she is very smart.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
In every thing but in loving Benedick.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Except for the fact that she loves Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Oh, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a
body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory.
I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and
her guardian.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Oh, my lord, when wisdom and passion are in one body, it's ten to one that the passion will win. I am sorry for her, as I should be, since I am both her uncle and her guardian.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
I would she had bestowed this dotage on me. I would have
daffed all other respects and made her half myself. I pray
you tell Benedick of it and hear what he will say.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I wish she were in love with me instead. I would have thrown away all other considerations and made her my wife. Please, tell Benedick about her feelings and see what he has to say.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Were it good, think you?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Is that a good idea, do you think?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he
love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known,
and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one
breath of her accustomed crossness.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Hero thinks Beatrice will surely die, for she says she'll die if he doesn't love her, and that she'll die before she tells him, and she'll die if he woos her and she's made to hold back even one of her usual insults.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
She doth well. If she should make tender of her love, 'tis
very possible he'll scorn it, for the man, as you know all,
hath a contemptible spirit.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
She's probably right. If she offers him her love, it's very possible that he'll scorn it, since, as we all know, he tends to be contemptuous.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
He is a very proper man.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
He's a very proper man.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
He hath indeed a good outward happiness.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Indeed, he is good-looking and carries himself well.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Before God, and in my mind, very wise.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
And I swear to God he's very smart.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
He does indeed show sparks of something like wit.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
And I take him to be valiant.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
And I believe him to be brave.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
As Hector, I assure you, and in the managing of quarrels
you may say he is wise, for either he avoids them with great
discretion or undertakes them with a most Christian-like
fear.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
As brave as
Hector, surely. And you could say that he is wise in managing fights, for he either avoids them discreetly or enters into them timidly.
Hector

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace. If he
break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear
and trembling.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
If he fears God, he must necessarily keep the peace. If he breaks the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
And so will he do, for the man doth fear God, howsoever it
seems not in him by some large jests he will make. Well, I
am sorry for your niece. Shall we go seek Benedick and tell
him of her love?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
And he'll do that, because he's a God-fearing man, even though his joking makes it seem otherwise. Well, I'm sorry for your niece. Should we go find Benedick and tell him about Beatrice's love?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Never tell him, my lord, let her wear it out with good
counsel.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
No, don't ever tell him, my lord. Let her get over it, with the help of good advice.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Nay, that's impossible. She may wear her heart out first.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
No, that's impossible. Her heart will break first.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter. Let it cool
the while. I love Benedick well, and I could wish he would
modestly examine himself to see how much he is unworthy
so good a lady.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Well, we'll hear more about it from your daughter. Let it sit for a while. I am very fond of Benedick, and I just wish he would take a look at himself and realize how unfairly he's treating this good woman.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
My lord, will you walk? Dinner is ready.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
My lord, will you come with me? Dinner is ready.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(aside to DON PEDRO and LEONATO) If he do not dote on her
(aside to
and
)
upon this, I will never trust my expectation.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(speaking so that only DON PEDROand LEONATO can hear) If he doesn't fall in love with her now, I'll never trust my intuition again.
(speaking so that only
and
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
(aside to LEONATO) Let there be the same net spread for her,
(aside to
)
and that must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry.
The sport will be when they hold one an opinion of
another's dotage, and no such matter. That's the scene that
I would see, which will be merely a dumb show. Let us send
her to call him in to dinner.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
(speaking so that only LEONATOcan hear) The same trap must be set for her; that's your daughter's and servants' job. The real fun will be when they both believe the other to be in love, without any of it being true. I can't wait to watch that drama - it'll be a pantomime, since both of them will be totally speechless! Let's send Beatrice to call Benedick in to dinner
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, and LEONATO
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
LEONATO
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except BENEDICK exits.
BENEDICK

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
(coming forward) This can be no trick. The conference was
(coming forward)
sadly borne; they have the truth of this from Hero; they
seem to pity the lady. It seems her affections have their full
bent. Love me? Why, it must be requited! I hear how I am
censured. They sy I will bear myself proudly if I perceive
the love come from her. They say, too, that she will rather
die than give any sign of affection. I did never think to
marry. I must not seem proud. Happy are they that hear
their detractions and can put them to mending. They say
the lady is fair; 'tis a truth, I can bear them witness. And
virtuous; 'tis so, I cannot reprove it. And wise, but for
loving me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no
great argument of her folly, for I will be horribly in love
with her! I may chance have some odd quirks and remnants
of wit broken on me because I have railed so long against
marriage, but doth not the appetite alter? A man loves the
meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age. Shall
quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the
brain awe a man from the career of his humor?
No! The world must be peopled. When I said I would die a
bachelor, I did not think I should live till I were married.
Here comes Beatrice. By this day, she's a fair lady. I do spy
some marks of love in her.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
(coming forward) This can't be a trick. They spoke with great seriousness, and they have Hero's testimony. They seem to pity the lady. It seems her love is stretched to the limit. She loves me? Well, that love must be returned! I hear how I'm criticized. They say I'll be smug if I find out she loves me. They also say she'd rather die than give any sign of her feelings. I never thought I'd marry. I can't appear to be proud. People who discover their faults and can then change them are lucky indeed. They say the lady is beautiful; it's true, I've seen it myself. And virtuous; that's true, I can't disprove that. And smart, except that she loves me. That may not be any proof of her intelligence, but I swear it won't be evidence of her stupidity - for I'm going to be horribly in love with her! People might tease me here and there, since I attacked marriage for so long. But don't tastes change? A man can love a dish when he is young that he hates when he turns old. Will quips and clever remarks and scathing written words keep a man from getting what his heart desires? No! The world needs to be populated. When I said that I'd die as a bachelor, I just meant that I didn't think I'd live until I got married. Here comes Beatrice. By God! She's a beautiful lady. I think I sense some signs of love in her.
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original:
Enter BEATRICE
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE enters.
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Against my will, I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Against my will, I've been told to bring you in to dinner.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Lovely Beatrice, I thank you for taking the pains to tell me that.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to
thank me. If it had been painful, I would not have come.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I didn't take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me. If the job had been painful, I would not have come.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
You take pleasure then in the message?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
So you took pleasure in bringing me this message?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's point and
choke a daw withal. You have no stomach, Signior. Fare you
well.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Yes, as much pleasure as one might take in choking a bird at knifepoint. You don't want to eat, sir? Goodbye, then.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Ha! "Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to
dinner." There's a double meaning in that. "I took no more
pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me."
That's as much as to say, "Any pains that I take for you is as
easy as thanks." If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.
If I do not love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Ha! "Against my will, I've been told to bring you in to dinner." There's a double meaning in that. "I didn't take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me." That's like saying, "Any thing I do for you is as easy as saying ‘thank you.'" If this doesn't move me to take pity on her, I'm a horrible person. If I don't love her, I'm completely
hard-hearted. I will go get her picture.
hard-hearted

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HERO,MARGARET, and URSULA
HERO
MARGARET
URSULA
paragraphs.translated:
HERO, MARGARET, andURSULA enter.
HERO
MARGARET
URSULA

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor.
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the Prince and Claudio.
Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula
Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse
Is all of her. Say that thou overheardst us,
And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower
Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun
Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it. There will she hide her
To listen our propose. This is thy office.
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Margaret, run into the sitting room. You'll find Beatrice there, talking to Claudio and the Prince. Whisper to her that Ursula and I are walking in the orchard and that we're talking all about her. Tell her you heard us, and that she should sneak into the arbor where the crisscrossing branches overhead keep the honeysuckles out of the sun. (The same honeysuckles that were once ripened in the sun; they're like courtiers who rise because the king favors them, then plot to overthrow his Majesty.) She can hide there and eavesdrop on our conversation. This is your job. Do it well, and then leave us.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
I'll make her come right away, I promise you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit.
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hearsay.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
All right Ursula, as Beatrice arrives, we'll be walking up and down this alley and speaking about nothing but Benedick. Whenever I mention him, praise him more than any man deserves. It'll be my job to talk about how Benedick is sick with love for Beatrice. We'll make our arrows the same way Cupid does: with gossip and rumor.

paragraphs.original:
Enter BEATRICE, behind
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE enters, behind.
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original:
Now begin,
For look where Beatrice like a lapwing runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.
paragraphs.translated: Let's start. See, Beatrice has run over like a little bird, keeping close to the ground and trying to overhear us.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
(aside to HERO)
(aside to
)
The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream
And greedily devour the treacherous bait.
So angle we for Beatrice, who even now
Is couchèd in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
(speaking so that only HERO can hear) The best part of fishing is watching the fish cut through the water and greedily take the bait. Now we're fishing for Beatrice, who's hiding right now in the honeysuckle arbor. Don't worry, I'll do my part.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
HERO
(aside to URSULA)
(aside to
)
Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it. - 
(approaching the bower)
(approaching the bower)
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful.
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
(speaking so that only URSULAcan hear) Then let's get closer, so she can hear all the false, sweet bait we're setting for her. -  (approaching the bower) No, truly, Ursula, she's too scornful. She's as devious and fierce as the wild hawks on the rocks.
(speaking so that only
can hear)
(approaching the bower)

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
But are you sure that Benedick loves Beatrice that much?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
So says the Prince and my new-trothèd lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
That's what the Prince and my fiancé say.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
And did they ask you to tell Beatrice about this, madam?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it,
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection
And never to let Beatrice know of it.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
They did want me to tell her, but I persuaded them that, if they truly loved Benedick, they would try to get him to battle his emotions and keep Beatrice in the dark.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Why did you do that? Doesn't Benedick deserve as much luck with a mate as he would have with Beatrice?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man,
But Nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice.
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprizing what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak. She cannot love
Nor take no shape nor project of affection
She is so self-endeared.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
By the god of love, I know that he deserves all that a man might possess. But Nature never made a woman's heart as proud and tough as Beatrice's. There is scorn and disdain in her eyes, and those sparkling eyes despise everything they look upon. She values her wit more highly than anything else, which looks weak by comparison. She's so in love with herself, she's incapable of loving anyone else. She can't even imagine what "love" is.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Sure, I think so,
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Yes, you're right. It would be bad if she knew about Benedick's love and teased him about it.

HERO
It's true. Whenever she meets a man - no matter how wise, noble, young, handsome - she rearranges all his good qualities so they end up looking bad. If he has a fair complexion, she'll say the pretty man should be her sister, not her husband. If he's dark-skinned, Nature must have spilled some ink while drawing his foolish face. If he's tall, she'll say he's a spear topped by an odd head; if he's short, she says he looks like a badly carved miniature. If he's talkative, he's a weathervane, moving in all directions at once; if he's silent, he's a block that can't be moved at all. And so she turns men inside out and never acknowledges the integrity and merit that a man has.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
It's true, her nitpicking is hardly admirable.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
No, not to be so odd and from all fashions
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable.
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air. O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
No, it certainly is not admirable to be so perverse and eccentric. But who would dare tell her? If I said something, she'd mock me so mercilessly that I'd probably disintegrate into air. She'd laugh me right out of my body and kill me with her wit.

paragraphs.original:
Therefore let Benedick, like covered fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.
paragraphs.translated: So Benedick should conceal his emotions. Like a fire that gets covered up, Benedick should smother his love and waste away. It would be better to die that way than to die from being mocked, which is as bad as being killed by tickling.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Yet tell her of it. Hear what she will say.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
But you should tell her about this, and hear what she has to say.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
No, rather I will go to Benedick
And counsel him to fight against his passion;
And truly I'll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with. One doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
No, instead I'll go to Benedick and advise him to fight his emotions. I'll make up some awful things about my cousin and ruin her reputation. You don't know how quickly affection can be killed with a single nasty word.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
O, do not do your cousin such a wrong!
She cannot be so much without true judgment,
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have, as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Oh, don't injure your cousin like that! With the quick, intelligent wit she's rumored to have, she can't really be such a bad judge of character that she'd refuse a man as exceptional as Signior Benedick.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
He is the only man of Italy,
Always excepted my dear Claudio.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
He's the only worthy man in Italy, aside from my dear Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy. Signor Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument and valor,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Don't be angry with me for speaking my mind, but throughout Italy, Benedick is considered the best man in looks, bearing, intelligence, and bravery.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
True, he has an excellent reputation.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
And he deserves it, having been excellent before he had a reputation for it. When are you getting married, madam?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Why, every day, tomorrow. Come, go in.
I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Tomorrow, and then every day after that. Come on, let's go inside. I want to show you some clothing, so you can tell me what I should wear tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: They move aside from the bower
paragraphs.translated: They move away from the bower.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
(aside to HERO)
(aside to
)
She's limed, I warrant you. We have caught her, madam.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
(speaking so that only HERO can hear) We caught her in our trap, madam, I'm sure of it.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

HERO
(speaking so that only URSULAcan hear) If so, then you never know where love will come from. Cupid gets some lovers with arrows, but some he lays traps for!
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt HERO andURSULA
HERO
URSULA
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone but BEATRICE exits.
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
(coming forward)
(coming forward)
What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemned for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand.
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band.
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
(coming forward) I'm burning up with shame! Can this be true? Do people criticize me this much for being proud and scornful? Then I'll say goodbye to my contempt and my pride in being unmarried! No good is spoken of such a person as me behind her back. Benedick, keep on loving me and I will return your love, like a wild hawk being tamed by her handler. I'll be kind to you from now on, and if you really do love me, that kindness will encourage you to seal our love with a wedding band. People say that you deserve my love, and I believe it - not just because they've said so.
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO BENEDICK, and LEONATO
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
BENEDICK
LEONATO
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO,BENEDICK, and LEONATO enter.
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
BENEDICK
LEONATO

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go
I toward Aragon.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I'll stay in Messina until you're married, and then I'll go to Aragon.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll vouchsafe me.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I'll go with you, my lord, if you'll allow me.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your
