marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to
wear it. I will only be bold with Benedick for his company,
for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all
mirth. He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's bow-string, and
the little hangman dare not shoot at him. He hath a heart as
sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his
heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
No, taking you away from your new marriage would be like showing a child a new coat and then not letting him wear it. I'll ask only Benedick to come with me, for from the top of his head to the soles of his feet he's a joker. He's evaded love once or twice, and since then Cupid doesn't dare to shoot at him. Benedick's heart is like a bell, with his tongue as the clapper: everything his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Gallants, I am not as I have been.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Gentleman, I am not the same man I was before.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
So say I. Methinks you are sadder.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I agree. I think you seem more serious.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I hope he be in love.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I hope he's in love.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Hang him, truant! There's no true drop of blood in him to
be truly touched with love. If he be sad, he wants money.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Come off it, man! There isn't a single drop of sincerity in him that could be touched with love. If he looks serious, he must need money.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
I have the toothache.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I have a
toothache.
toothache

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Draw it.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Draw it.
Draw it.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Hang it!
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Hang it!
Hang it!

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
You have to hang it first. Then you can
draw it.
draw

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
What, sigh for the toothache?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What, are you moaning on about your toothache?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Where is but a humor or a worm.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
It could only have been caused by some humor or
worm.
worm

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Well, everyone can master a grief but he that has it.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Well, everyone knows how to overcome an injury except the one who actually has one.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Yet say I, he is in love.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I repeat, he's in love.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy
that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutchman
today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two
countries at once, as a German from the waist downward,
all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet.
Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath,
he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
No, there's no love in him, unless you mean his love for strange costumes. He's a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, and sometimes wears the clothing of two countries at once: a German from the waist down, with his baggy pants, and a Spaniard from the hips up, with a cloak and no jacket. Unless you're talking about his love for this kind of foolishness - which, judging from his appearance, he has - he is no fool for love, as you pretend.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing
old signs. He brushes his hat o' mornings. What should
that bode?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
If he's not in love with a woman, then you can't trust the usual symptoms. He brushes his hat in the mornings. What do you think that means?

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Hath any man seen him at the barber's?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Has any man seen him at the barber's?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him, and the
old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
No, but the barber's assistant has been seen with him. The beard that used to decorate Benedick's cheeks has been shaved off and is now stuffing
tennis balls.
tennis balls

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Getting rid of the beard definitely makes him look younger.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Nay, he rubs himself with civet. Can you smell him out by
that?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
And he's rubbed himself with perfume. Can you smell out his secret now?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
That's as good as proof that the sweet young man's in love.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
The greatest note of it is his melancholy.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
The biggest clue is his seriousness.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
And when was he wont to wash his face?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
And when has he ever been known to wash his face?

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Yea, or to paint himself? For the which I hear what they say
of him.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Yes, or to wear cosmetics? I hear what they say about him for doing that.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute
string and now governed by stops -
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Indeed, his mocking spirit has now crawled into a
lute, and he can be played like an instrument - 
lute

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him. Conclude, conclude,
he is in love.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Truly, it all adds up to a serious story for Benedick. A conclusion, a conclusion: he is in love.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Nay, but I know who loves him.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Oh, and I know who loves him.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
That would I know too. I warrant, one that knows him not.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I bet I know, too: someone who clearly doesn't know him at all.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Yes, and his ill conditions, and, in despite of all, dies for
him.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
No, she does know him, and she also knows all his bad qualities - and in spite of all this, she still dies for him.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
She shall be buried with her face upwards.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
She'll be buried with her face upwards, then.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Yet is this no charm for the toothache. - Old Signior, walk
aside with me. I have studied eight or nine wise words to
speak to you, which these hobbyhorses must not hear.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
This chatter is no cure for my toothache. (to LEONATO) Old sir, please walk with me a bit. I have eight or nine well-considered words to say to you, and I don't want these fools to hear.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt BENEDICK andLEONATO
BENEDICK
LEONATO
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK and LEONATO exit.
BENEDICK
LEONATO

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
For my life, to break with him about Beatrice!
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I bet my life he's gone to speak with Leonato about Beatrice!

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this played their
parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite one
another when they meet.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
It must be. By now, Hero and Margaret have done their part with Beatrice. The two bears won't bite each other the next time they meet.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON JOHN
DON JOHN
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN enters.
DON JOHN

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
My lord and brother, God save you.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
My lord and brother, God save you.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Good e'en, brother.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Good evening, brother.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
If your leisure served, I would speak with you.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
If you don't mind, I'd like to speak with you.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
In private?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
In private?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
If it please you. Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I
would speak of concerns him.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
If you wish. But Count Claudio can stay, for what I'm about to say concerns him.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
(to CLAUDIO) Means your lordship to be married tomorrow?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
(to CLAUDIO) Do you plan on getting married tomorrow?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
You know he does.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
You know that he does.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
I know not that, when he knows what I know.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
I don't know that, once he knows what I know.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
If there's any reason we shouldn't get married, I urge you to tell me.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
You may think I love you not. Let that appear hereafter, and
aim better at me by that I now will manifest. For my
brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart
hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage - surely suit ill
spent and labor ill bestowed.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
You may think that I don't love you. I hope that, after I tell you my news, you will think better of me. My brother thinks highly of you, and because of his affection, has helped arrange your marriage - but that was definitely a waste of his time and energy.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Why, what's the matter?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Why, what's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances shortened, for
she has been too long a-talking of, the lady is disloyal.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
I came here to tell you - I'll make this short, since she's already been talked about for too long - the lady is unfaithful.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Who, Hero?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Who, Hero?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Even she: Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
That's the one: Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Disloyal?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Unfaithful?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
The word is too good to paint out her wickedness. I could
say she were worse. Think you of a worse title, and I will fit
her to it. Wonder not till further warrant. Go but with me
tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even
the night before her wedding day. If you love her then,
tomorrow wed her. But it would better fit your honor to
change your mind.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
The word is too good to represent her wickedness. She is worse than wicked. If you can think of a more awful title, I'll call her that. But don't keep wondering without more proof. Come with me tonight, and you'll see a man enter her bedroom chamber - even tonight, the night before her wedding. If you still love her after that, then marry her tomorrow. But you would be more honorable if you changed your mind.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(to DON PEDRO) May this be so?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(to DON PEDRO) Is this possible?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
I will not think it.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I won't consider it.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know.
If you will follow me, I will show you enough, and when
you have seen more and heard more, proceed accordingly.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
If you won't risk coming to see her tonight, then don't claim to know what she's like. If you follow me, I'll give you all the proof you need. Once you have seen more and heard more, then you can decide what to do.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
If I see anything tonight why I should not marry her,
tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there
will I shame her.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
If I see anything tonight that convinces me not to marry her, I'll shame her tomorrow in the very congregation where I would have married her.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
And as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee
to disgrace her.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
And since I wooed her in your name, I'll join you in disgracing her.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
I will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses.
Bear it coldly but till midnight and let the issue show itself.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
I won't say anything else about her until you two see things for yourselves. Remain calm until midnight, and then you'll see what the trouble is.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
O day untowardly turned!
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Oh, this day has turned into a disaster!

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
O mischief strangely thwarting!
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Oh, mischief has ruined our plans!

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
O plague right well prevented! So will you say when you
have seen the sequel.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
Oh, a plague has been prevented, thank God! That's what you'll say once you've seen part two.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DOGBERRY andVERGES with the Watch
DOGBERRY
VERGES
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY and VERGES with several of the Prince's
WATCHMEN enter.
DOGBERRY



VERGES
WATCHMEN

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Are you good men and true?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Are you all good and honest men?

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation,
body and soul.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Yes they are, otherwise it would be proper for them to suffer
salvation, body and soul.
salvation

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they
should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the
Prince's watch.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
If they had any
allegiance when they were chosen for the Prince's watch, a punishment like that would be too good for them.
allegiance

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Well, give them their charge, neighbor Dogberry.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Well, give them their assignment, Sir Dogberry.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
First, who think you the most desartless man to be constable?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
First, which man do you think is most
desertless to be leader of the watch?
desertless

paragraphs.original:
FIRST WATCHMAN
Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole, for they can write
and read.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN
Either Hugh Otecake, sir, or else George Seacole, because both of them can read and write.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Come hither, neighbor Seacole. God hath blessed you with
a good name. To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune,
but to write and read comes by nature.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Come here, Sir Seacole. God has blessed you with a good name. To be good-looking is a matter of luck, but to read and write is a natural gift.

paragraphs.original:
SEACOLE
Both which, Master Constable -
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND WATCHMAN
Both of which, master constable -

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
You have. I knew it would be your answer. Well, for your
favor, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it,
and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there
is no need of such vanity. You are thought here to be the
most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch;
therefore bear you the lantern. This is your charge:
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
You have. I knew that would be your answer. Well, for your good looks, sir, thank God and don't boast about it. As for your reading and writing, use those skills when you can't use your looks. You're thought to be the most
senseless and fit man here, so you will carry the lantern and be constable. This is your assignment:
senseless

paragraphs.original:
you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are to bid any
man stand, in the Prince's name.
paragraphs.translated:
you will
comprehend any vagrant men you see. You are to order all men to stop, in the Prince's name.
comprehend

paragraphs.original:
SECOND WATCHMAN
How if he will not stand?
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND WATCHMAN
And what if he won't stop?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go and
presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God
you are rid of a knave.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Well then, don't bother with him and let him go. Then immediately call the rest of the watch together and thank God that you've gotten rid of such a criminal.

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the
Prince's subjects.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
If he won't stop when he's told to, then he isn't one of the Prince's subjects.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
True, and they are to meddle with none but the Prince's
subjects. - You shall also make no noise in the streets; for,
for the watch to babble and to talk is most tolerable and not
to be endured.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
True, and you aren't supposed to meddle with anyone but the Prince's subjects. You will also stay quiet in the streets, for a babbling watch is most
tolerable and will not be endured.
tolerable

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
We will rather sleep than talk. We know what belongs to a
watch.
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
We'll sleep instead of talk. We know what's appropriate for a watch.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman,
for I cannot see how sleeping should offend. Only have a
care that your bills be not stolen. Well, you are to call at all
the alehouses and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Why, you speak like an experienced and quiet watchman. Sleeping on the watch shouldn't be a problem; just make sure that your weapons don't get stolen. Also, you're supposed to visit all the bars and tell anyone who's drunk to go home and go to bed.

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
How if they will not?
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
And what if they won't go?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Why, then, let them alone till they are sober. If they make
you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the
men you took them for.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Well then, leave them alone until they're sober. If even then they don't answer to your satisfaction, you can say that they're not the men you thought they were.

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
Well, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
Very good, sir.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your
office, to be no true man, and for such kind of men, the less
you meddle or make with them, why the more is for your
honesty.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
If you meet a thief, you can expect him to be dishonest. The less you have to do with that kind of man, the more honest you will be.

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
So if we know that a man is a thief, should we try to arrest him?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Truly, by your office you may, but I think they that touch
pitch will be defiled. The most peaceable way for you, if
you
do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is and steal
out of your company.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Your position permits you to, but I think that those who stick their hands in
pitch get their hands dirty. If you encounter a thief, I think the most peaceable thing to do is to let him be himself - and steal away.
pitch

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
You have been always called a merciful man, partner.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
You have always been known as a merciful man, partner.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man
who hath any honesty in him.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Truly, I wouldn't even hang a dog, much
more a man who has any honesty in him.
more

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
(to the Watch) If you hear a child cry in the night, you must
(to the Watch)
call to the nurse and bid her still it.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
(to the watchmen) If you hear a child crying in the night, you should call the nurse and tell her to quiet the child.
(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
What if the nurse is asleep and doesn't hear us?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Why then, depart in peace and let the child wake her with
crying, for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baas
will never answer a calf when he bleats.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Well then, leave quietly, and let the child's crying wake up the nurse. The ewe that doesn't go to her lamb when it baas will never tend to another animal's child.
baas

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
'Tis very true.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
That's very true.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
This is the end of the charge. You, constable, are to present
the Prince's own person. If you meet the Prince in the night,
you may stay him.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
And that's the end of your assignment. You, constable, are representing the Prince himself. If you meet the Prince in the night, you can order him to stop.

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Nay, by 'r Lady, that I think he cannot.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
No, by our Lady, I don't think he can.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Five shillings to one on 't, with any man that knows the
statutes, he may stay him - marry, not without the Prince
be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man,
and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
I'll bet any man who knows the law five shillings to one on it. Truly though, you can't stop the Prince without the Prince's consent, for the watch shouldn't offend anyone, and it's an offense to keep a man without his consent.

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
By 'r lady, I think it be so.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
By our Lady, I think that's true.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Ha, ha, ha! - Well, masters, good night.
An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me. Keep your fellows'
counsels and your own; and good night. - Come, neighbor.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Ha, ha, ha! Well, gentlemen, good night. And if anything important happens, find me and let me know. Keep each other's secrets and your own. Good night. Come, friend.

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
Well, masters, we hear our charge. Let us go sit here upon
the church bench till two, and then all to bed.
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
Well gentlemen, we've heard our assignment. Let's sit here on the church bench until two and then go off to bed.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
One word more, honest neighbors. I pray you watch about
Signior Leonato's door, for the wedding being there
tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight. Adieu, be vigitant,
I beseech you.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
One more thing, good gentlemen. Watch over Signior Leonato's house; with the wedding being held there tomorrow, there's a great to-do there tonight. Adieu. Be
vigitant, I beg you.
vigitant

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt DOGBERRY andVERGES
DOGBERRY
VERGES
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY and VERGES exit.
DOGBERRY
VERGES

paragraphs.original:
Enter BORACHIO andCONRADE
BORACHIO
CONRADE
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO and CONRADE enter.
BORACHIO
CONRADE

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
What Conrade!
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Conrade!

paragraphs.original:
SEACOAL
(aside) Peace! Stir not.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
(whispering) Quiet! Don't move!
(whispering)

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Conrade, I say!
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Conrade, I say!

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Here, man. I am at thy elbow.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
I'm here, man, at your elbow.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Mass, and my elbow itched, I thought there would a scab
follow.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Come to think of it, I thought I felt a scab there.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
I will owe thee an answer for that. And now forward with
thy tale.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
I'll get you for that. Now get on with your story.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles
rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Since it's drizzling, stand under this overhang with me and, like a true drunk, I'll tell you everything.

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
(aside) Some treason, masters. Yet stand close.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
(speaking so that only the other WATCHMEN can hear) There's some treason occurring, gentlemen. Stay here.
(speaking so that only the other
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand
ducats.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
You should know I've earned a thousand gold pieces from Don John.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Is it possible that any crime could be so valuable?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy
should be so rich. For when rich villains have need of poor
ones, poor ones may make what price they will.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
You should ask instead if it's possible that any criminal could be so rich. Because when rich villains need poor villains' services, those poor ones can name the price.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
I wonder at it.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
I can't believe it.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that the
fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
That only proves how inexperienced you are. You know that the style of a man's jacket or hat or coat means nothing.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Yes, it is apparel.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Yes, it's just clothing.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
I mean the fashion.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
No, I mean, the fashion of a man's clothing tells us nothing about the man.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Yes, the fashion is the fashion.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Yes, fashion is fashion.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Tush, I may as well say the fool's the fool. But seest thou not
what a deformed thief this fashion is?
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
C'mon, I might as well say the fool's the fool! But don't you see what a
deformed villain fashion is?
deformed

paragraphs.original:
WATCHMAN
(aside) I know that Deformed. He has been a vile thief this
(aside)
seven year. He goes up and down like a gentleman. I
remember his name.
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN
(speaking so that only the other WATCHMEN can hear) I know that man,
Deformed. For the past seven years, he's been a wicked thief. He walks around as if he were a gentleman. I remember that name.
(speaking so that only the other
can hear)
Deformed

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Didst thou not hear somebody?
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Did you hear someone?

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
No, 'twas the vane on the house.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Just the weathervane moving.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is,
how giddily he turns about all the hot bloods between
fourteen and five-and-thirty, sometimes fashioning them
like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reechy painting, sometime
like god Bel's priests in the old church-window, sometime
like the shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten
tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
As I was saying, fashion is a deformed villain. It makes hot-blooded young men spin around feverishly, forever changing their appearances, dictating that sometimes they dress like Pharoah's soldiers in that grimy painting and sometimes like the priests of the god Baal, as seen in old church windows. And sometimes fashion dresses them like the great Hercules in that dirty, worm-eaten tapestry - the one where his
codpiece seems almost as big as his club.
codpiece

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
All this I see, and I see that the fashion wears out more
apparel than the man. But art not thou thyself giddy with
the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into
telling me of the fashion?
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
I get all this. And I also understand how fashion changes so quickly that a man's clothing never gets a chance to wear itself out. But you're all wound up about fashion, too. Otherwise, why would you stray from your story to blabber on about it?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Not so, neither. But know that I have tonight wooed
Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the name of
Hero. She leans me out at her mistress' chamber window,
bids me a thousand times good night. I tell this tale vilely.
I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio and my
master, planted and placed and possessed by my master
Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable
encounter.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
No, I'm not wound up. But I will tell you that I seduced Margaret, the Lady Hero's waiting woman, tonight. I called her "Hero" the whole time. She leaned out of her mistress's bedroom window and told me good night a thousand times - but I am telling this story poorly. I should backtrack and begin with how my master, Don John, arranged for the Prince, Claudio, and himself to witness this friendly encounter from the orchard.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
And thought they Margaret was Hero?
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
And they thought Margaret was Hero?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the devil my
master knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths,
which first possessed them, partly by the dark night, which
did deceive them, but chiefly by my villainy, which did
confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went
Claudio enraged, swore he would meet her as he was
appointed next morning at the temple, and there, before the
whole congregation, shame her with what he saw o'ernight
and send her home again without a husband.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
The Prince and Claudio did, but the devil, my master, knew that it was Margaret. They believed the charade partially because of my master's testimony - which first caused them to doubt Hero - and partially because of how dark and deceiving the night was, but mostly because of my villainous actions, which confirmed Don John's slander. Claudio went away enraged, swearing that he'd meet Hero at the temple as planned and there, before the entire congregation, shame her with what he'd discovered and send her home without a husband.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND WATCHMAN
We charge you, in the Prince's name, stand!
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND WATCHMAN
We charge you, in the Prince's name, to stop!

paragraphs.original:
FIRST WATCHMAN
Call up the right Master Constable. We have here
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was
known in the commonwealth.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN
Call up the Master Constable Dogberry. We have
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that was ever known in the commonwealth.
recovered

paragraphs.original:
SECOND WATCHMAN
And one Deformed is one of them. I know him; he wears a
lock.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND WATCHMAN
And one of them is the criminal Deformed. I know him; he wears a lock of hair.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Masters, masters -
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Gentlemen, gentlemen -

paragraphs.original:
SECOND WATCHMAN
(to BORACHIO) You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I
(to
)
warrant you.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND WATCHMAN
(to BORACHIO) I bet you'll be forced to bring Deformed forward.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
FIRST WATCHMAN
Masters, never speak, we charge you, let us obey you go
with us.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN
Gentlemen, don't speak. We
obey you to go with us.
obey

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of
these men's bills.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
We're probably a very valuable catch for these guys.

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
A commodity in question, I warrant you. - Come, we'll
obey you.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Well, our value is debatable, I bet. Let's go, we'll obey you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter HERO,MARGARET, and URSULA
HERO
MARGARET
URSULA
paragraphs.translated:
HERO, MARGARET, andURSULA enter.
HERO
MARGARET
URSULA

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to
rise.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Good Ursula, go wake my cousin and ask her to get up.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
I will, lady.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
I will, lady.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
And bid her come hither.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
And request that she come here.

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Well.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Very well.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Troth, I think your other rebato were better.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Really, I think your other ruff is better.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
No, please good Meg, I'll wear this one.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
By my troth, 's not so good, and I warrant your cousin will
say so.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Honestly, it's not as good as the other one, and I'm sure your cousin will agree with me.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
My cousin's a fool, and thou art another. I'll wear none but
this.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
My cousin's a fool, and you are too. I'll wear this one and none other.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a
thought browner; and your gown's a most rare fashion, i'
faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown that they praise so.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
I like your new wig and headdress, though I'd like it more if the hair were a shade browner. And your gown is really stylish. You know, I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown, the one that everyone praises so highly.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Oh, that exceeds, they say.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Oh, they say that dress surpasses all others.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
By my troth, 's but a nightgown in respect of yours - cloth
o' gold, and cuts, and laced with silver, set with pearls,
down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne
with a bluish tinsel. But for a fine, quaint, graceful, and
excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on 't.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Compared to your dress, it's no better than a nightgown. The cloth is interwoven with gold thread, and slashes in the material show the fabric beneath. It is trimmed with silver lace and embroidered with pearls. It has one set of fitted sleeves and another ornamental pair that hangs open from the shoulders. The skirts are trimmed with a blue, metallic fabric. But for a fine, elegant, graceful, and excellent dress, yours is worth ten of those.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding heavy.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
I hope I enjoy wearing it, for my heart is very heavy.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
It will be made even heavier soon - by the weight of a man.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Fie upon thee! Art not ashamed?
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Watch your tongue! Have you no shame?

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Of what, lady? Of speaking honorably? Is not marriage
honorable in a beggar? Is not your lord honorable without
marriage? I think you would have me say, "Saving your
reverence, a husband." An bad thinking do not wrest true
speaking, I'll offend nobody. Is there any harm in "the
heavier for a husband"? None, I think, an it be the right
husband and the right wife. Otherwise, 'tis light and not
heavy. Ask my Lady Beatrice else. Here she comes.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Shame of what, lady? Sex and marriage are honorable things - even for a beggar, right? And isn't your husband an honorable man? You're so prudish you'd probably like me to say, "I beg your pardon, your husband" - as if husband were a dirty word! So long as suspicious minds aren't misinterpreting my honest words, I'll offend no one. What's wrong with admitting your husband's going to lie on you? Nothing, as long as it's the right husband with the right wife. That's right and proper - anything else is frivolous and immoral. Ask Beatrice. Here she comes.
husband

paragraphs.original:
Enter BEATRICE
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE enters.
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Good morrow, coz.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Good morning, cousin.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Good morrow, sweet Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Good morning, sweet Hero.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Why, how now? Do you speak in the sick tune?
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Why do you sound so odd? Are you ill? You sound out of tune.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I am out of all other tune, methinks.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I must be ill - I don't think I can speak in any other tune.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Clap 's into "Light o' love." That goes without a burden.
Do you sing it, and I'll dance it.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
If it's a tune we want, let's sing "Light on Love!" It's a light song and doesn't require a man to sing the baritone. You sing, and I'll dance.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Ye light o' love, with your heels! Then, if your husband
have stables enough, you'll see he shall lack no barns.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
You're "light on love" sure enough - your frivolous dancing proves you have light heels! When you're married one of these days, if your husband is rolling in dough, you'll let him roll in the hay whenever he wants.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Never! I reject that life; I kick it away with my
heels.
heels

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin. 'Tis time you were ready.
By my troth, I am exceeding ill. Heigh-ho!
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
(to HERO) It's almost five o'clock, cousin. You should be ready by now. Oh, I really don't feel well. Heigh-ho!
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Are you sighing for a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
For the letter that begins them all, H.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I have an ache; I'm sighing for the letter that begins all those words.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Well, an you be not turned Turk, there's no more sailing by
the star.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Well, if you haven't
renounced your old faith yet, we can't trust anything anymore.
renounced

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
What means the fool, trow?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
What does the fool mean by that, I wonder?

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Nothing, I; but God send everyone their heart's desire.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
I don't mean anything - but God sends everyone their heart's desire.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent
perfume.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
The Count sent me an excellent pair of perfumed gloves.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I am stuffed, cousin. I cannot smell.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Sorry, I'm all stuffed. I can't smell a thing.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
A maid, and stuffed! There's goodly catching of cold.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Oh, just a young lady and already
stuffed! That's a nice way to catch a cold.
stuffed!

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Oh, God help me, God help me! How long have you
professed apprehension?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Oh, God help me! Since when have you claimed to be such a great wit?

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Ever since you lost yours. Doesn't my wit suit me well?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
It is not seen enough; you should wear it in your cap. By my
troth, I am sick.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
It doesn't get seen enough; you should wear it in your cap, the way fools wear coxcombs. God, I'm really sick.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Get you some of this distilled carduus benedictus and lay it
to your heart. It is the only thing for a qualm.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
You should get some distilled
carduus benedictus and put it on your chest. It's the only way to cure a sudden faintness.
carduus benedictus

paragraphs.original:
HERO
There thou prick'st her with a thistle.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
With that you've managed to prick her with a thistle.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Benedictus! Why benedictus? You have some moral in this
benedictus?
benedictus?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Benedictus! Why do you suggest I use benedictus? Is there some double meaning in that word, "benedictus"?
Benedictus
benedictus

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Moral! No, by my troth, I have no moral meaning. I meant
plain holy thistle. You may think perchance that I think you
are in love. Nay, by 'r Lady, I am not such a fool to think
what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I
cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that
you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be
in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he
become a man. He swore he would never marry, and yet
now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without
grudging. And how you may be converted I know not, but
methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Double meaning! No, honestly, there's no other meaning. I just meant that you should use some holy thistle. Maybe you think that I think you're in love. No, by Our Lady, I'm not such a fool to think what I please, and I don't please to think what I can, and in fact I cannot think, even if I could think my heart right past thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or even that you can be in love. But Benedick was once an enemy of love as well, and now he's become a real man. He swore that he'd never get married, but now, despite his earlier protestations, he loves ungrudgingly. How we're going to convert you I'll never know. And yet I think you look with your eyes just like every other woman does.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Why are you talking at such a crazy clip?

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Not a false gallop.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
It's not a false gallop, anyway.

paragraphs.original:
Enter URSULA
URSULA
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA enters.
URSULA

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Madam, withdraw: the Prince, the Count, Signor
Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town are
come to fetch you to church.
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Madam, we have to go: the Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gentlemen of the town have come to bring you to church.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Good cousin, good Meg, good Ursula, come help me get dressed.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter LEONATO withDOGBERRY and VERGES
LEONATO
DOGBERRY
VERGES
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO enters withDOGBERRY andVERGES.
LEONATO
DOGBERRY
VERGES

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
What would you with me, honest neighbor?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
What do you want from me, my good man?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you that
decerns you nearly.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Please, sir, I would like to discuss some news that
decerns you greatly.
decerns

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Brief, I pray you, for you see it is a busy time with me.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Be brief, please, because, as you can see, this is a busy time for me.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Marry, this it is, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Indeed, sir, it is.

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Yes, in truth it is, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Yes, it truly is.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
What is it, my good friends?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
What's the news, my good friends?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter. An old
man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would
desire they were, but, in faith, honest as the skin between
his brows.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Sorry, sir, Goodman Verges tends to ramble. He's an old man, sir, and his wits are not as
blunt as I wish they were. But truly, he's as honest as the skin between his brows.
blunt

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living that is an
old man and no honester than I.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Yes, I thank God that I am as honest as all the other old men who are not honester than me.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Comparisons are odorous. Palabras, neighbor Verges.
Palabras
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Making comparisons is
odorous, Verges. Get on with your story.
odorous

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Neighbors, you are tedious.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Friends, you are becoming tedious.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
It pleases your Worship to say so, but we are the poor duke's
officers. But truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as
a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your
worship.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Thank you for saying that, your Worship, but we're just the poor duke's officers. But truly, if I were as
tedious as a king, I would give everything to you, your Worship.
tedious

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
All thy tediousness on me, ah?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Oh, so you'd give me all your tediousness?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis, for I hear
as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the
city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Yes, even if I had a thousand more pounds than that, for I hear that you are
exclaimed throughout the city, and though I am only a poor man, it makes me glad to hear it.
exclaimed

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
And so am I.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Me, too.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I would fain know what you have to say.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Gentlemen, please, I'd like to hear your news.

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your Worship's
presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant knaves as any in
Messina.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Sir, our watch tonight - 
expectfully, sir - has captured a couple of the worst criminals in Messina.
expectfully

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
A good old man, sir. He will be talking. As they say, "When
the age is in, the wit is out." God help us, it is a world to see!
Well said, i' faith, neighbor Verges. - Well, God's a good
man. An two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An
honest soul, i' faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke
bread, but God is to be worshipped, all men are not alike,
alas, good neighbor!

LEONATO
Indeed, neighbor, he comes too short of you.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Truly, my friend, he isn't nearly as impressive as you are.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Gifts that God gives.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
God gives those gifts - I had nothing to do with it.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I must leave you.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Now I must return to the wedding.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
One word, sir. Our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended
two aspicious persons, and we would have them this
morning examined before your worship.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
One more thing, sir. Our watch, sir, as you know, has
comprehended two auspicious persons. We'd like for you to examine them this morning.
comprehended

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Take their examination yourself and bring it me. I am now
in great haste, as it may appear unto you.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Examine them yourselves, then bring me your findings. Now I'm in a great hurry, as I'm sure you can see.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
It shall be suffigance.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
That will be
suffigance.
suffigance

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Drink some wine ere you go. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Have some wine before you go. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original:
Enter a MESSENGER
MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated:
A MESSENGER enters.
MESSENGER

paragraphs.original:
MESSENGER
My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her
husband.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSENGER
My lord, they're waiting for you to give your daughter away to Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I'll wait upon them. I am ready.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I'm coming.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt LEONATO andMESSENGER
LEONATO
MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO and theMESSENGER exit.
LEONATO
MESSENGER

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole. Bid him
bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail. We are now to
examination these men.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Go to Francis Seacole, the constable of the watch. Tell him to bring his pen and his inkwell to the jail. We will now go to
examination these men.
examination

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
And we must do it wisely.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
We must do this wisely.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
We will spare for no wit, I warrant you. Here's that shall
drive some of them to a noncome. Only get the learned
writer to set down our excommunication and meet me at
the jail.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
We won't hold back any of our wisdom. We'll drive them to a
noncome. Go get the educated writer to record our excommunication, and I'll meet you at the jail.
noncome

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,HERO, BEATRICE, and Attendants
DON PEDRO
DON JOHN
LEONATO
FRIAR FRANCIS
CLAUDIO
BENEDICK
HERO
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO, DON JOHN,LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS,CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,HERO, and BEATRICE enter withATTENDANTS.
DON PEDRO
DON JOHN
LEONATO
FRIAR FRANCIS
CLAUDIO
BENEDICK
HERO
BEATRICE
ATTENDANTS

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Come, Friar Francis, be brief, only to the plain form of
marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties
afterwards.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
All right, Friar Francis, let's keep this short. Do a simple ceremony, and list all the particular duties of marriage later.

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
(to CLAUDIO) You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
(to CLAUDIO) Have you come here, my lord, to marry this lady?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
No.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
No.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
To be married to her. - Friar, you come to marry her.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
No, he comes to be married to her. Friar, you are the one who has come to marry her.
to

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Lady, you come hither to be married to this count?
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Lady, do you come here to be married to this count?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
I do.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
I do.

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
If either of you know any inward impediment why you
should not be conjoined, charge you on your souls to utter
it.
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
If either of you knows any secret reason why you two should not be joined in marriage, I order you on your souls to say so.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Know you any, Hero?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Do you know any, Hero?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
None, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
None, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Know you any, count?
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Do you know any, count?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I dare make his answer, none.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I'm sure I can answer for him - he doesn't know any, either.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
O, what men dare do! What men may do! What men daily
do, not knowing what they do!
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Oh, the things men dare to do! The things men are allowed to do! The things men do daily, not knowing what they're doing!

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
How now, interjections? Why, then, some be of laughing,
as, ah, ha, he!
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
What, are we playing with interjections? Well then, add some interjections that indicate laughter, like
"ah," "ha," and "he!"
"ah," "ha," and "he!"

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Stand thee by, Friar. - Father, by your leave,
Will you with free and unconstrainèd soul
Give me this maid, your daughter?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Hold on, Friar. (to LEONATO) Father, are you giving me your daughter freely?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
As freely, son, as God did give her me.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
As freely, son, as God gave her to me.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
And what have I to give you back whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
And what should I give you that would be equal in value to this rare and precious gift?

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Nothing, unless you render her again.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Nothing, sir, except grandchildren.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness. - 
There, Leonato, take her back again.
Give not this rotten orange to your friend.
She's but the sign and semblance of her honor.
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
Oh, what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood as modest evidence
To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,
All you that see her, that she were a maid
By these exterior shows? But she is none.
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Good Prince, you have taught me how to accept things nobly. There, Leonato, take your daughter back. Don't insult a friend by giving him a beautiful orange that rots inside. She only appears honorable from the outside. Look, how she blushes like a virgin! Oh, sin can disguise itself so artfully! Doesn't that rising blush suggest that she is virtuous and innocent? All of you who are looking at her, wouldn't you swear that she's a virgin, judging by these outward shows? But she is no virgin. She has been in a man's bed. She blushes from guilt, not modesty.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
What do you mean, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
What do you mean, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approvèd wanton.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I won't be married. I won't join my soul to such a proven slut.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Dear my lord, if you in your own proof
Have vanquished the resistance of her youth
And made defeat of her virginity -
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
My dear lord, if it was you who conquered her and took her virginity -

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I know what you would say: if I have known her,
You will say she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the forehand sin.
No, Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large
But, as a brother to his sister, showed
Bashful sincerity and comely love.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I know what you're about to say. If I had slept with her, you'd say that we did so as husband and wife, merely anticipating our eventual marriage. No, Leonato. I never seduced her, or tempted her with indecent words. I treated her like a brother would treat a sister, with modest sincerity and appropriate affection.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
And seemed I ever otherwise to you?
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
And have I ever seemed less than modest or appropriate to you?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Out on thee, seeming! I will write against it.
You seem to me as Dian in her orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown.
But you are more intemperate in your blood
Than Venus, or those pampered animals
That rage in savage sensuality.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Curse you for your false appearances! To me, you seemed like
Diana in her orbit - as virginal as the flower bud before it blooms. But you're actually as hot-blooded as Venus, or a pampered animal allowed to run wild.
Diana

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Are you sick, my lord? Is that why you're talking so wildly?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Sweet Prince, why speak not you?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Good Prince, say something!

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
What should I speak?
I stand dishonored, that have gone about
To link my dear friend to a common stale.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What should I say? I've been dishonored: I arranged for a friend of mine to marry a common whore.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Are you really saying these things, or am I dreaming?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
They're really being spoken, sir, and they're true.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
This looks not like a nuptial.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
This doesn't look like a wedding.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
True! O God!
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
It's true! Oh God!

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince's brother?
Is this face Hero's? Are our eyes our own?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Leonato, am I standing here? Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince's brother? Is this face Hero's? Are these our eyes?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
All this is so, but what of this, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Yes, that's all true - but what do you mean by it, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Let me but move one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Let me just ask her one question, and by your authority as her father, order her to answer truthfully.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
As my child, I order you to do so.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Oh, God defend me! how am I beset! - 
What kind of catechizing call you this?
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Oh, God help me! How I'm being attacked! What kind of game is this?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
To make you answer truly to your name.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
We just want you to answer to your real name.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name
With any just reproach?
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
Isn't my name Hero? Who can stain that name with a just accusation?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Marry, that can Hero!
Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue.
What man was he talked with you yesternight
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Indeed, Hero herself can! You've stained your virtue with your own actions. What man were you talking to at your window last night, between the hours of midnight and one? If you're a virgin, you'll answer this question.

paragraphs.original:
HERO
I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
I wasn't talking to any man at that time, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Why, then are you no maiden. - Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear. Upon mine honor,
Myself, my brother, and this grievèd count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window
Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,
Confessed the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Well then, you are no virgin. Leonato, I'm sorry you have to hear this. I swear on my honor that we saw and heard Hero talking to a brute at her window last night.
And that man confessed at length how he has secretly come to her bedroom thousands of times.

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Fie, fie, they are not to be named, my lord,
Not to be spoke of!
There is not chastity enough in language,
Without offense, to utter them. - Thus, pretty lady,
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
No, my lord, don't name her sinful acts or speak of them! There's no way to describe them without offending everyone here. Pretty lady, I'm much ashamed of your shocking behavior.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been
If half thy outward graces had been placed
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! Farewell,
Thou pure impiety and impious purity.
For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love,
And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Oh Hero, you could have equaled the
mythical Hero if only half your outward beauty matched your inner thoughts and desires! Goodbye, beautiful sinner. Goodbye to your pure wickedness and your wicked purity. Because of you, I'll keep myself away from love. I'll hang suspicion on my eyelids, so that all the beautiful things I see are transformed into dangers and are never able to trick me again.
mythical Hero

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Hath no man's dagger here a point for me?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Does anyone have a dagger for me?

paragraphs.original:
HERO swoons
HERO
paragraphs.translated:
HERO faints.
HERO

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
What's wrong, cousin? Why have you collapsed?

paragraphs.original:
DON JOHN
Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up.
paragraphs.translated:
DON JOHN
Come, let's go. These revelations have overwhelmed her.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO
DON PEDRO
DON JOHN
CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO exit.
DON PEDRO
DON JOHN
CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
How doth the lady?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
How is she?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Dead, I think. - Help, uncle! - 
Hero, why, Hero! Uncle! Signor Benedick! Friar!
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
She's dead, I think. - Help, uncle! - Hero, why Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
O Fate! Take not away thy heavy hand!
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wished for.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Oh Fate, don't spare Hero from being punished! Death is the best way to cover over her shame.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
How now, cousin Hero!
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
How are you, Hero?

paragraphs.original:
HERO stirs
HERO
paragraphs.translated:
HERO stirs.
HERO

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
(to HERO) Have comfort, lady.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
(to HERO) Take comfort, lady.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
(to HERO) Dost thou look up?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
(to HERO) Are you looking up?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Yea, wherefore should she not?
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Yes, why shouldn't she?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing
Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood? - 
Do not live, Hero, do not ope thine eyes,
For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,
Strike at thy life. Grieved I I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugal Nature's frame?
O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggar's issue at my gates,
Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy,
I might have said, "No part of it is mine;
This shame derives itself from unknown loins"?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Why not! Isn't every living thing condemning her? Can she deny the accusations that are proven by her guilty blush? Die, Hero, don't open your eyes. If I didn't think you were about to die soon - if I thought your spirit could bear this shame - I would risk punishment and kill you myself. Am I sorry that I only had one child? Do I blame Nature for being so thrifty? Oh, one child is one too many! Why did I ever have one? Why did you once seem lovely to me? Why didn't I just adopt a beggar's child left at my doorstep, whose shame and dishonor I could have denied, not being its true father?
But you were mine, and I loved and praised you for being mine, and was proud of you for being mine - I loved you so much that I hardly cared about myself.

paragraphs.original:
But mine, and mine I loved, and mine I praised,
And mine that I was proud on, mine so much
That I myself was to myself not mine,
Valuing of her - why, she, O she is fall'n
Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again
And salt too little which may season give
To her foul tainted flesh!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, but now you have fallen into a pit of ink, and there's not enough water in the whole wide sea to wash you clean again, and not enough salt to cover your stink.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Sir, sir, be patient.
For my part, I am so attired in wonder
I know not what to say.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Sir, sir, calm down. I'm so amazed by this, I don't know what to say.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Oh, on my soul, my cousin is belied!
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Oh, on my soul, my cousin has been slandered falsely!

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Lady, did you sleep in her room last night?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
No, truly not, although until last night
I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
No, I didn't, but I did every night for the past year.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Confirmed, confirmed! Oh, that is stronger made
Which was before barred up with ribs of iron!
Would the two princes lie and Claudio lie,
Who loved her so that, speaking of her foulness,
Washed it with tears? Hence from her. Let her die.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Then it's confirmed! That's even more proof, and the case against her was airtight already. Would the two princes and Claudio lie? Claudio, who loved her so much that talking about her wickedness made him weep?

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Hear me a little,
For I have only silent been so long,
And given way unto this course of fortune,
By noting of the lady. I have marked
A thousand blushing apparitions
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes,
And in her eye there hath appeared a fire
To burn the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool,
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Listen to me a moment. I've only remained silent this whole time because I've been watching Hero. I've seen her begin to blush a thousand times, only to watch those blushes disappear a thousand times and an innocent paleness take over her face. And in her eyes I see a fire that would seem to burn away the lies the princes have told about her chastity. Call me a fool,

don't trust my observations - the truth of which is backed up by all my years of experience - don't trust my age, my reputation, my position, and my holiness.

paragraphs.original:
Trust not my reading nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenor of my book; trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
Under some biting error.
paragraphs.translated: You can doubt all these things if this sweet lady turns out to be guilty.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Friar, it cannot be.
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left
Is that she will not add to her damnation
A sin of perjury. She not denies it.
Why seek'st thou then to cover with excuse
That which appears in proper nakedness?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
But she must be, Friar. You see that any morals she has left are preventing her from denying the charges: she doesn't want to add perjury to her list of sins.

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Lady, what man is he you are accused of?
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Lady, who do they accuse you of having taken as your lover?

paragraphs.original:
HERO
They know that do accuse me. I know none.
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy! - O my father,
Prove you that any man with me conversed
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintained the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!
paragraphs.translated:
HERO
You should ask them. I don't know who they're talking about. If I've been with a man in any improper way, let all my sins be punished! Oh, father, if you yourself can prove that I talked with a man at an indecent hour, or indeed that I spoke to any creature last night, you can disown me, hate me, and torture me to death!

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
There is some strange misprision in the princes.
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
The princes are under some strange misunderstanding.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Two of them have the very bent of honor,
And if their wisdoms be misled in this,
The practice of it lives in John the Bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Two of them are completely honorable, and if they have been tricked in this, we must blame John the Bastard, who lives to create conflict.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I know not. If they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine
Nor age so eat up my invention
Nor fortune made such havoc of my means
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends
But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,
Both strength of limb and policy of mind,
Ability in means and choice of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I don't know. If they have spoken the truth about Hero, I will tear her apart with my bare hands. But if they have accused her falsely, even the greatest of them will have to deal with me. Age hasn't dried up my body or eroded my intelligence so much, and luck hasn't robbed me of so much of my fortune, and my bad ways
haven't deprived me of so many friends, that they won't find me ready to seek revenge both physically and mentally, with money and friends at my disposal.

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Pause awhile,
And let my counsel sway you in this case.
Your daughter here the princes left for dead.
Let her awhile be secretly kept in
And publish it that she is dead indeed.
Maintain a mourning ostentation,
And on your family's old monument
Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites
That appertain unto a burial.
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Hold on a moment, and listen to my advice. The princes left your daughter here for dead. Hide her for a while in your house, and tell everyone that she has, in fact, died. Make a bug show of mourning for her, hang sad epitaphs up at your family's tomb, and perform all the appropriate burial ceremonies.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
What shall become of this? What will this do?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Why should we do this? What will this do?

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Marry, this, well carried, shall on her behalf
Change slander to remorse. That is some good.
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth.
She, dying, as it must so be maintained,
Upon the instant that she was accused,
Shall be lamented, pitied and excused
Of every hearer. For it so falls out
That what we have we prize not to the worth
Whiles we enjoy it, but being lacked and lost,
Why then we rack the value, then we find
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
Listen, if we do this correctly, the men who slandered Hero will feel remorse for her instead. That will be a good thing. But I have an even greater goal in mind. We'll maintain that she died the instant she was accused, and everyone who hears this will grieve for her, pity her, and excuse her actions. That's how it goes: we don't value the things we have until we lose them, when we suddenly rack up their value and see

all the virtues we were blind to when they were alive and with us. That's how Claudio will respond. When he hears that she died from his words, his imagination will be sweetly overtaken by thoughts of her. In death, every aspect of her life will be got up more beautifully, and in his mind she will seem more moving, more delicate, and more lively even than when she was alive. Then, if he ever truly felt love, he'll mourn and wish he hadn't accused her - even though he believed his accu-

paragraphs.original:
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio.
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
The idea of her life shall sweetly creep
Into his study of imagination,
And every lovely organ of her life
Shall come apparelled in more precious habit,
More moving, delicate and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul
Than when she lived indeed. Then shall he mourn,
If ever love had interest in his liver,
And wish he had not so accused her,
No, though he thought his accusation true.
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be leveled false,
The supposition of the lady's death
Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.
paragraphs.translated: sation to be true. Follow my plan, and trust that the actual events will play out even better than I am describing. And even if they don't, at least Hero's supposed death will stop the rumors of her infidelity. And if it doesn't go well, then you can keep her hidden in a nunnery, the best place for someone with her kind of dirtied reputation - away from the public's eyes, tongues, mind, and insults.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you.
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Signior Leonato, listen to the friar's plan. And even though you know I'm very close to the Prince and Claudio, I swear I'll keep your counsel and deal with this secretly and justly.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Because I'm drowning in my grief, I'll grab onto the smallest piece of string dangled in front of me.

paragraphs.original:
FRIAR FRANCIS
'Tis well consented. Presently away,
For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure. - 
Come, lady, die to live. This wedding day
Perhaps is but prolonged. Have patience and endure.
paragraphs.translated:
FRIAR FRANCIS
This is a good agreement. Now, let's go. A strange disease requires a strange cure. Come, lady; you must die in order to live. Hopefully, your wedding day is only postponed. Have patience and endure.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt all but BENEDICK andBEATRICE
BENEDICK
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone but BENEDICK andBEATRICE exits.
BENEDICK
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Lady Beatrice, have you been crying this entire time?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Yea, and I will weep a while longer.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Yes, and I'll keep crying a while longer.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
I will not desire that.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I don't wish that on you.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
You have no reason. I do it freely.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
You don't have to; I do it of my own free will.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I really believe your cousin was falsely accused.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would
right her!
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Oh, the man who avenged her could ask anything of me!

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Is there any way to show such friendship?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Is there any way I could show such friendship to you?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
A very even way, but no such friend.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
A very clear way, but there is no friend who will undertake it.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
May a man do it?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Can a man do it?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
It is a man's office, but not yours.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
It's a job meant for a man, but not you.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
I do love nothing in the world so well as you. Is not that
strange?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
There is nothing in the world that I love as much as you. Isn't that strange?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
As strange as the thing I know not. It were as possible for
me to say I loved nothing so well as you, but believe me not,
and yet I lie not, I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am
sorry for my cousin.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
It's as strange as this other thing which I don't understand. I could just as easily say that there is nothing in the world that I love as much as you. But don't believe me - though I'm not lying. I confess nothing, and I deny nothing. I feel awful for my cousin.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
By my sword, Beatrice, you love me.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Do not swear, and eat it.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Don't swear like that and then go back and
eat it later.
eat it

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
I will swear by it that you love me, and I will make him eat
it that says I love not you.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I'll swear by my
sword that you love me, too, and I'll make any man who says that I don't love you eat it.
sword

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Will you not eat your word?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
But you won't eat your words?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
