With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest I love thee.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Not with any sauce they could provide for them. I swear, I love you.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Why then, God forgive me.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Well then, God forgive me!

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
What offense, sweet Beatrice?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Why, what have you done, sweet Beatrice?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
You have stayed me in a happy hour. I was about to protest
I loved you.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
You got to me first. I was about to swear that I loved you.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
And do it with all thy heart.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Then do so, with all your heart.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to
protest.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I love you with so much of my heart that none of it is left to protest with.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Come, bid me do anything for thee.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Come, ask me to do anything for you.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Kill Claudio.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Kill Claudio.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Ha! Not for the wide world.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Ha! I wouldn't do that for the whole wide world.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
You kill me to deny it. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Then, rejecting my request, you kill me, instead. Goodbye.
me,

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE begins to exit
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE begins to exit.
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Tarry, sweet Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Wait, sweet Beatrice.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
I am gone, though I am here. There is no love in you. Nay,
I pray you let me go.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
My body waits here, but the rest of me is gone. You don't really love me. I beg you to let me go.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Beatrice -
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Beatrice -

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
In faith, I will go.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I swear, I'm going.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
We'll be friends first.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Not until we part as friends.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine
enemy.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
How dare you try to be my friend when you refuse to fight my enemy.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Is Claudio thine enemy?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Is Claudio your enemy?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Is he not approved in the height a villain, that hath
slandered, scorned, dishonored my kinswoman? Oh, that I
were a man! What, bear her in hand until they come to take
hands and then, with public accusation, uncovered
slander, unmitigated rancor - O God, that I were a man! I
would eat his heart in the marketplace.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Hasn't he proven himself to be a great villain - slandering, scorning, and dishonoring my cousin? Oh, I wish I were a man! He pretended that everything was fine until the moment they were exchanging vows, and then - with public accusation, blatant slander, pure hatred - Oh God, if only I were a man! I would rip his heart out in public and eat it.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Hear me, Beatrice -
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Listen to me, Beatrice -

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Talk with a man out at a window! A proper saying!
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Talking with a man outside her bedroom window! A likely story!

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Nay, but Beatrice -
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
No, but Beatrice -

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered, she is
undone.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Sweet Hero, she's been wronged, she's been slandered, she's been ruined.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Beat -
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Beat -

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Princes and counties! Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly
count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely! Oh, that I
were a man for his sake! Or that I had any friend would be
a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into curtsies,
valor into compliment, and men are only turned into
tongue, and trim ones too. He is now as valiant as Hercules
that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be a man with
wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Princes and counts! Oh, of course, it was all so proper and ceremonious - they gave a truly princely testimony. He's a proper count, that Count Sugarplum, a sweet gentleman, for sure! Oh, if only I were a man! Or had a friend who would be a man for me! But there are no real men left. Their manliness has melted into pretty curtsies and fancy manners, and their bravery is spent on making clever compliments. All this conversing has turned men into tongues - and fancy ones, at that. The man who tells a lie and swears by it is now considered as brave as Hercules. I can't make myself a man by wishing I were, so as a woman I'll die, from grieving.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Wait, good Beatrice. I swear by this hand that I love you.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Don't just swear by it; put your hand to some use that will prove you love me.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged
Hero?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Do you honestly think, in your soul, that Claudio has wrongly accused
Hero?
Hero?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Yes, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Enough, I am engaged. I will challenge him. I will kiss your
hand, and so I leave you. By this hand, Claudio shall render
me a dear account. As you hear of me, so think of me. Go
comfort your cousin. I must say she is dead, and so,
farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
That's enough for me, then. I'll challenge him. I'll kiss your hand, and with that I leave you. I swear that Claudio will pay dearly for this. Keep me in your thoughts and go comfort your cousin. I'll go tell them that she's dead. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

DOGBERRY

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Is our whole dissembly appeared?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Is our whole
dissembly here?
dissembly

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Oh, a stool and a cushion for the Sexton.

VERGES
Oh, we need a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

A stool is brought in. SEXTON sits
SEXTON
paragraphs.translated:
A stool is brought in. The SEXTON sits down.
SEXTON

paragraphs.original:
SEXTON
Which be the malefactors?
paragraphs.translated:
SEXTON
Which ones are the malefactors?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Marry, that am I and my partner.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Sir, that would be me and my partner.

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Nay, that's certain; we have the exhibition to examine.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Yes, yes, we've been
exhibitioned to examine this case.
exhibitioned

paragraphs.original:
SEXTON
But which are the offenders that are to be examined? Let
them come before Master Constable.
paragraphs.translated:
SEXTON
No, you've misunderstood me - where are the criminals whom I'm supposed to examine? Have them come in front of the master constable.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Yea, marry, let them come before me.
What is your name, friend?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Yes, indeed, bring them before me.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO andCONRADE come forward
BORACHIO
CONRADE
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO and CONRADE come forward.
BORACHIO
CONRADE

paragraphs.original: What's your name, friend?
paragraphs.translated: What's your name, friend?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Borachio.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Borachio.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Pray, write down, "Borachio." - Yours, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Please, write down "Borachio." - And yours?

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
I'm a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Write down "Master Gentleman Conrade." - Masters, do
you serve God?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Write down "Master Gentleman Conrade." - Gentlemen, are you good Christians, and do you serve God?

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE, BORACHIO
Yea, sir, we hope.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE, BORACHIO
Yes, sir, we hope so.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Write down that they hope they serve God; and write God
first, for God defend but God should go before such
villains! - Masters, it is proved already that you are little
better than false knaves, and it will go near to be thought so
shortly. How answer you for yourselves?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Write down that they hope they serve God. Oh, and write "God" first - for God forbid we put these criminals before God! - Gentlemen, it's already been proven that you aren't much better than lying criminals, and soon we'll know almost for certain. How do you both plead?

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Marry, sir, we say we are none.
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Honestly, sir, we say that we are not criminals.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
A marvelous witty fellow, I assure you, but I will go about
with him. - Come you hither, sirrah, a word in your ear.
Sir, I say to you it is thought you are false knaves.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
He's a marvelously witty fellow, no doubt, but I'll outmaneuver him. - Come over here; I'll whisper a word in your ear. Sir, I tell you we believe you're both lying criminals.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Sir, I say to you we are none.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Sir, I tell you that we are not.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Well, stand aside. - 'Fore God, they are both in a ale. Have
you writ down that they are none?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Well, okay. - I swear to God, both their stories match. Have you written that down, that they aren't criminals?

paragraphs.original:
SEXTON
Master Constable, you go not the way to examine. You
must call forth the watch that are their accusers.
paragraphs.translated:
SEXTON
Master Constable, you're going about this all wrong. First, you have to speak to the watchmen who accused them.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Yea, marry, that's the eftest way. - Let the watch come
forth. Masters, I charge you in the Prince's name, accuse
these men.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Yes, good idea; that's the
eftest way. Bring the watchmen forward. Gentlemen, I order you in the Prince's name to accuse these men.
eftest

paragraphs.original:
FIRST WATCHMAN
This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince's brother, was
a villain.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN
This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince's brother, was a villain.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Write down Prince John a villain. Why, this is flat perjury,
to call a prince's brother villain.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Write down that Prince John is a villain. Why, that's flat-out
perjury - to call a prince's brother a villain.
perjury

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Master Constable -
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Master Constable -

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Pray thee, fellow, peace. I do not like thy look, I promise
thee.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Be quiet, you. I swear, I don't like the look of you.

paragraphs.original:
SEXTON
(to Watch) What heard you him say else?
(to Watch)
paragraphs.translated:
SEXTON
(to the watchmen) What else did you hear him say?
(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original:
SECOND WATCHMAN
Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John
for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND WATCHMAN
That Don John had given him a thousand pieces of gold for wrongfully accusing the Lady Hero.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Flat burglary as ever was committed.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
That's burglary, that is.

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Yea, by Mass, that it is.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Yes, by God, that it is.

paragraphs.original:
SEXTON
What else, fellow?
paragraphs.translated:
SEXTON
What else did you hear?

paragraphs.original:
FIRST WATCHMAN
And that Count Claudio did mean upon his words to
disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not marry
her.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN
I heard that Count Claudio meant to disgrace Hero in front of the whole wedding party and refuse to marry her.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
(to BORACHIO) O villain! Thou wilt be condemned into
(to
)
everlasting redemption for this.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
(to BORACHIO) Oh, you villain! You'll be condemned to everlasting
redemption for this!
(to
)
redemption

paragraphs.original:
SEXTON
What else?
paragraphs.translated:
SEXTON
What else?

paragraphs.original:
FIRST WATCHMAN
This is all.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN
That's all.

paragraphs.original:
SEXTON
And this is more, masters, than you can deny. Prince John
is this morning secretly stolen away. Hero was in this
manner accused, in this very manner refused, and upon the
grief of this, suddenly died. - Master Constable, let these
men be bound and brought to Leonato's. I will go before
and show him their examination.
paragraphs.translated:
SEXTON
(to CONRADE and BORACHIO) You can't deny this, gentlemen. This morning, Prince John secretly snuck out of Messina. Hero was accused exactly as the watchman described, and died on the spot from the grief.
(to
and
)
Master Constable, tie up these men and bring them to Leonato's. I'll get there first and tell him what we found out.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Come, let them be opinioned.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Come on, let's get them
opinioned.
opinioned

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Let them be in the hands -
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Let them be in the hands -

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Off, coxcomb!
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Get off me, you fool!

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
God's my life, where's the Sexton? Let him write down the
Prince's officer "coxcomb." Come, bind them. - Thou
naughty varlet!
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Honest to God, where's the sexton? He should write down that the Prince's officer was called a fool. Come on, tie them up. (to CONRADE) You're a nasty little stinker!
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CONRADE
Away! You are an ass, you are an ass!
paragraphs.translated:
CONRADE
Get away from me, you ass! You ass!

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost thou not suspect my
years? Oh, that he were here to write me down an ass! But
masters, remember that I am an ass, though it be not
written down, yet forget not that I am an ass. - No, thou
villain, thou art full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by
good witness. I am a wise fellow and, which is more, an
officer and, which is more, a householder and, which is
more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in Messina, and one
that knows the law, go to, and a rich fellow enough, go to,
and a fellow that hath had losses, and one that hath two
gowns and everything handsome about him. - Bring him
away. - Oh, that I had been writ down an ass!
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
How can you call me that? Don't you suspect my office? Don't you
suspect my age? Oh, if only the sexton were here to write down that I'm an ass! Gentlemen, remember that I am an ass; even though it's not written down, don't forget that I'm an ass. Oh, you're a rotten bastard, you are. I'm a wise man and, what's more, I'm an officer of the law and, what's more, I'm a householder and, what's more, I'm as handsome a hunk of meat as any in Messina. And I know the law, damn you, and I'm rich enough, damn you, and I used to have more, but I still have two robes and lots of lovely things. - Take him away! - Oh, if only the sexton had recorded that I'm an ass!
suspect

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter LEONATO andANTONIO
LEONATO
ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO and ANTONIO enter.
LEONATO
ANTONIO

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
If you go on thus, you will kill yourself,
And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief
Against yourself.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
If you keep on the way you've been going, you'll kill yourself. There's no point in adding to your grief.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I pray thee, cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless
As water in a sieve. Give not me counsel,
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine,
And bid him speak of patience.
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine,
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form.
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
Bid sorrow wag, cry "hem" when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk
With candle-wasters, bring him yet to me
And I of him will gather patience.
But there is no such man. For, brother, men
Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief
Which they themselves not feel, but, tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion which before
Would give preceptial med'cine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air, and agony with words.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Stop advising me; your words pass through my ears like water through a sieve. Don't counsel me. Only someone who's been wronged as I have can comfort me. Find a father who loved his child as overwhelmingly as I loved Hero and askhim to be patient. Compare the length and width of that man's sadness against my own; match up all the complaints and strong emotions that run through our bodies. If a man who has suffered as I have gave me advice the way you do - smiling and stroking his beard, telling me to toss away my sorrow, giving speeches when he should be wailing with me, trying to heal my grief with little proverbs, spinning my head around with philosophy - then I would take his advice and be patient. But that man doesn't exist. You can try to comfort a man who feels a pain that you have never felt, but once you feel it too, your sober advice will also turn into passion. You can't treat madness with rules or bind up insanity with little silken threads or cure heartache with hot air or lighten agony with pat phrases.
him

paragraphs.original:
No, no, 'tis all men's office to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow,
But no man's virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral when he shall endure
The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel.
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.
paragraphs.translated: Every man thinks it's his duty to advise those who are overwrought with sorrow to be patient. But no man is so moral or so strong that they can endure the same advice when they themselves are grieving. So don't advise me. My sorrow is crying too loudly to hear what you have to say.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Therein do men from children nothing differ.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Well then you're no better than a child.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood,
For there was never yet philosopher
That could endure the toothache patiently,
However they have writ the style of gods
And made a push at chance and sufferance.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Please, leave me alone. I intend to be flesh and blood, not airy philosophy, for there has never yet been a philosopher who could endure a toothache patiently, even though they all write as if they had risen above human suffering and misfortune.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself.
Make those that do offend you suffer too.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
But don't take all that pain on yourself. Make sure the ones who have wronged you suffer too.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
There thou speak'st reason. Nay, I will do so.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied,
And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince
And all of them that thus dishonor her.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Now you're talking. I definitely will. In my soul, I believe Hero has been falsely accused. And I'll make sure that Claudio, the Prince, and anyone else who helped dishonor her know about it.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO enter.
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
The Prince and Claudio are hurrying this way.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Good e'en, good e'en.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Good evening, good evening.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Good day to both of you.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Good day to both of you.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Hear you, my lords -
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Listen, my lords -

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
We have some haste, Leonato.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
We're in a bit of a hurry, Leonato.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Some haste, my lord! Well, fare you well, my lord.
Are you so hasty now? Well, all is one.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
A bit of a hurry, my lord! Well then, good bye, my lord. You're in a hurry, are you? Well then, don't bother.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Come on, don't quarrel with us, good old man.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
If he could right himself with quarreling,
Some of us would lie low.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
If it's fighting he is after, some of us here should run and hide.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Who wrongs him?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Who has wronged him?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou.
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword.
I fear thee not.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Indeed, you have wronged me, you liar. Don't bother trying to intimidate me by putting your hand on your sword. I'm not scared of you.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Marry, beshrew my hand
If it should give your age such cause of fear.
In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Curse my hand if it ever threatened an old man like you. Really, I had no intention of going for my sword.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me.
I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag
What I have done being young, or what would do
Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,
Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me
That I am forced to lay my reverence by,
And with gray hairs and bruise of many days
Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors,
Oh, in a tomb where never scandal slept
Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Damn you, don't mock and sneer at me. I'm not a doddering old fool who brags about the things he did when he was young, and what he would do now if he weren't so old. Claudio, I'm telling you right to your face that you have wronged me and my innocent child. I am forced to lay aside my old man's respectability, and with my gray hairs and my aching body I challenge you to a duel. You have ruined my innocent child. Your slander has broken her heart, and now she lies buried with her ancestors in a tomb - ancestors who had never been tainted by scandal until you caused one with your wickedness.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
My villainy?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
My wickedness?

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Yours, Claudio, yours, I say.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
You say not right, old man.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
You've got it wrong, old man.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
My lord, my lord,
I'll prove it on his body if he dare,
Despite his nice fence and his active practice,
His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
My lord, if he dares to accept my challenge, I'll beat him and prove he's guilty. I'll beat him despite his fancy fencing techniques and all the practicing he does, despite his youth and manliness.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Away! I will not have to do with you.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Not a chance! I'll have nothing to do with you.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast killed my child.
If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
You think you can get rid of me that easily? You killed my child. Take on someone your own size: if you kill me, boy, you'll have killed a man.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
He shall kill two of us, and men indeed,
But that's no matter. Let him kill one first.
Win me and wear me! Let him answer me. - 
Come, follow me, boy. Come, sir boy, come, follow me.
Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
He'll have to kill both of us, and indeed we're both men. But let him start off easy by killing one of us. Come on - kill me and brag about it! Let me at him. Come on, come after me, little boy. Come on and get me. Little man, I'll be right in your face with my sword. I will, as surely as I am a gentleman.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Brother -
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Brother -

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece,
And she is dead, slandered to death by villains
That dare as well answer a man indeed
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue. - 
Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Quiet. God knows I loved my niece, and now she's dead - slandered to death by cowards who would just as likely fight a real man as I would grab a poisonous snake by the tongue. Boys, fools, braggers, scoundrels, babies!

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Brother Anthony -
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Brother Anthony -

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple - 
Scrambling, outfacing, fashion-monging boys,
That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,
Go anticly and show outward hideousness,
And speak off half a dozen dang'rous words
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst,
And this is all.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Hold your peace. I know their kind, I know them exactly. They're petulant, disrespectful, fashion-crazy boys who lie and cheat and mock, defame and slander. They walk around in outlandish outfits, pretending to be brave and wild and saying a few inflammatory things about how they'll hurt their enemies - and that's all they do.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
But brother Anthony -
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
But brother Anthony -

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Come, 'tis no matter.
Do not you meddle. Let me deal in this.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Don't, it's no big deal. Don't bother with it. Let me deal with this.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
My heart is sorry for your daughter's death,
But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing
But what was true and very full of proof.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Gentlemen, we won't stay here and anger you further. I'm sorry about your daughter's death, but I swear our accusations were true, and backed up with proof.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
My lord, my lord -
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
My lord, my lord -

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
I will not hear you.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
I don't want to hear any more about it.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
No? Come on, brother! I'm determined to be heard by someone.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
And shall, or some of us will smart for it.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
And you will be, or some people here will suffer for it.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt LEONATO andANTONIO
LEONATO
ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO and ANTONIO exit.
LEONATO
ANTONIO

paragraphs.original:
Enter BENEDICK
BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK enters.
BENEDICK

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Look, here comes just the man we were looking for.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Now, Signior, what news?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
What's up, mister?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
(to DON PEDRO) Good day, my lord.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
(to DON PEDRO) Hello, my lord.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Welcome, Signior. You are almost come to part almost a
fray.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Welcome, sir. You just missed a fight that was barely
avoided.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two
old men without teeth.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
We were about to have our noses snapped off by two
old men with no teeth.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Leonato and his brother. What think'st thou? Had we
fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Leonato and his brother. What do you think? I think
if we had fought, we would have proven too young and
strong for them after all.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
In a false quarrel there is no true valor. I came to seek you
both.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
There's no bravery in an unfair fight. I've been look-
ing for you two.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
We have been up and down to seek thee, for we are high-
proof melancholy and would fain have it beaten away. Wilt
thou use thy wit?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
We've been looking for you, too. We're really
depressed. Will you tell us some jokes to beat our sad-
ness away?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
It is in my scabbard. Shall I draw it?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
My wit's in my
scabbard. Should I unsheath it?
scabbard

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
You wear your wit next to you?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Never any did so, though very many have been beside their
wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels: draw to
pleasure us.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
No one carries their wit next to them, though some
people are
beside their wit. Come on, draw your wit,
beside their wit



just as musicians draw their bows across the instru-
ments: draw for our pleasure.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
As I am an honest man, he looks pale. - Art thou sick, or
angry?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Look: Benedick is so pale - are you sick, or angry?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(to BENEDICK) What, courage, man! What though care
(to
)
killed a cat? Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(to BENEDICK) Buck up, man!
Care may have killed the
(to
)
Care



cat, but you are strong enough to kill care. Lighten up.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, an you charge it
against me. I pray you, choose another subject.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Sir, don't even try to beat me in a battle of wits. I'll
meet all your attacks, even if you come charging at me
with a lance at full gallop. Choose another tack.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(to DON PEDRO) Nay, then, give him another staff. This last
(to
)
was broke 'cross.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(to DON PEDRO) That was poor, Benedick! Give him
(to
)
another lance - that last one got broken in half.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
By this light, he changes more and more. I think he be angry
indeed.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Lord, he seems to be getting paler by the minute. I
think he really is angry.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
If he is, that's his problem.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Shall I speak a word in your ear?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Can I have a word with you privately?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
God bless me from a challenge!
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
God forbid he wants to challenge me!

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
(aside to CLAUDIO) You are a villain. I jest not. I will make it
(aside to
)
good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you
dare. Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice. You
have killed a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on
you. Let me hear from you.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
(speaking so that only CLAUDIOcan hear) You are a vil-
(speaking so that only
can hear)
lain. I'm not kidding. I challenge you however you
like - with whatever weapons you choose, and whe-
never you want. Meet this challenge, or I'll say that
you're a coward. You've killed an innocent woman,
and you're going to pay dearly for her death. What do you say?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I'll be there, and I'll enjoy myself.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
What, a feast, a feast?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What, are we having a feast?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I' faith, I thank him. He hath bid me to a calf's head and a
capon, the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my
knife's naught. Shall I not find a woodcock too?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Yes, we are. He has invited me to have a
calf's head and a capon. He says if I don't carve them up and serve them elegantly, he'll declare I have no skills with a knife. Should I go get us a woodcock, too?
calf's head and a capon

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Sir, you have a very slow, rambling wit.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit he other day. I
said thou hadst a fine wit. "True," said she, "a fine little
one." "No," said I, "a great wit." "Right," says she, "a great
gross one." "Nay," said I, "a good wit." "Just," said she, "it
hurts nobody." "Nay," said I, "the gentleman is wise."
"Certain," said she, "a wise gentleman." "Nay," said I, "he
hath the tongues." "That I believe," said she, "for he swore
a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on
Tuesday morning; there's a double tongue, there's two
tongues." Thus did she an hour together transshape thy
particular virtues. Yet at last she concluded with a sigh,
thou wast the proper'st man in Italy.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Benedick, Beatrice praised your wit the other day. I said you had a fine wit. "True," she said, "a fine little one." "No," I said, "a huge wit." "Right," she said, "a hugely awful one." "No," I said, "he has a good wit." "Exactly," she said, "it's good and mild; it doesn't hurt anyone." "No," I said, "Benedick is wise." "He is certainly," she said,
"a wise gentleman.""No," I said, "he can speak many languages:" "I can believe that," she said, "because he swore one thing to me on Monday night and took it back on Tuesday morning. He spoke two languages then." She turned all your virtues into vices just about an hour ago. But in the end she sighed and admitted you were the handsomest man in Italy.
"a wise gentleman."

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
For the which she wept heartily and said she cared not.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
She cried a lot at that, and said she didn't care.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Yea, that she did. But yet for all that, an if she did not hate
him deadly, she would love him dearly. The old man's
daughter told us all.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
That she did. And yet for all that, if she didn't hate him to death, she'd love him to death. Leonato's daughter had told us everything.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
All, all. And, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in
the garden.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Absolutely everything. And, moreover, God saw Benedick when he was hid in the garden.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on the sensible
Benedick's head?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
But when exactly will we see Benedick married?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Yea, and text underneath: "Here dwells Benedick the
married man"?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Yes, with the sign underneath him that says: "Here lives Benedick the married man"?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Fare you well, boy. You know my mind. I will leave you now
to your gossip-like humor. You break jests as braggarts do
their blades, which, God be thanked, hurt not. - My lord,
for your many courtesies I thank you. I must discontinue
your company.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Goodbye, boy. You know what I intend. I'll leave you now to chatter and gossip like an old woman. The wit you flaunt is like a blunt sword - it can't hurt anyone, thank God. - My lord, I thank you for your many kindnesses. I'm leaving your court now.

paragraphs.original:
Your brother the Bastard is fled from Messina. You have
among you killed a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord
Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be
with him.
paragraphs.translated: Your brother Don John the Bastard has run away from Messina. The three of you have killed a sweet, innocent woman. Lord Babyface over there will meet me in a duel, and good luck to him then.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
He is in earnest.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
He's serious.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
In most profound earnest, and, I'll warrant you, for the love
of Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Very serious, and I'm sure it's because of Beatrice.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
And hath challenged thee?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
And he challenged you to a duel?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Most sincerely.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
He did, very sincerely.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and
hose and leaves off his wit!
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What a strange sight - a man who has put on all his fancy clothes but forgotten his brain at home!

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to
such a man.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
A guy like that is bigger than an ape, but the ape could be his doctor, it's so much smarter.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
But soft you, let me be. Pluck up, my heart, and be sad. Did
he not say my brother was fled?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
But wait a minute. Let me gather my wits and get serious here. Didn't he say my brother has run away?

paragraphs.original:
Enter DOGBERRY,VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO
DOGBERRY
VERGES
CONRADE
BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the WATCHMEN enter with CONRADE and BORACHIO.
DOGBERRY
VERGES
WATCHMEN
CONRADE
BORACHIO

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Come you, sir. If justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er
weigh more reasons in her balance. Nay, an you be a cursing
hypocrite once, you must be looked to.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Come on, you. If they let you off, then we'll have to assume that Lady Justice has lost all her power. Since you are a lying hypocrite, we must look after you.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
How now? Two of my brother's men bound! Borachio one!
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
What's this? Two of my brother's men, all tied up! And Borachio is one of them!

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Hearken after their offense, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Find out what they're being held for.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
Officers, what offense have these men done?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Officers, what crime have these men committed?

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover,
they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders;
sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have
verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying
knaves.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Well sir, they've lied; moreover, they have said things that were not true; secondarily, they are slanderers; sixth and lastly, they have falsely accused a lady; thirdly, they have confirmed things that did not in fact happen; and, in conclusion, they are lying scoundrels.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee
what's their offense; sixth and lastly, why they are
committed; and, to conclude, what you lay to their charge.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
First, I ask you what they've done; thirdly, I ask you what offense they're charged with; sixth and lastly, I ask you why they've been committed here; and, in conclusion, I ask what they're accused of.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Rightly reasoned, and in his own division; and, by my
troth, there's one meaning well suited.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Nicely done, and organized in just the way he'll understand. My God, he manages to say the same thing six different ways.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
(to BORACHIO and CONRADE) Who have you offended,
(to
and
)
masters, that you are thus bound to your answer? This
learned constable is too cunning to be understood. What's
your offense?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
(to BORACHIO and CONRADE) What have you done, gentlemen? This educated constable is too brilliant for me to understand. What is your crime?
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Sweet Prince, let me go no farther to mine answer. Do you
hear me, and let this count kill me. I have deceived even your
very eyes. What your wisdoms could not discover, these
shallow fools have brought to light, who in the night
overheard me confessing to this man how Don John your
brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero, how you
were brought into the orchard and saw me court Margaret in
Hero's garments, how you disgraced her when you should
marry her. My villainy they have upon record, which I had
rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame. The
lady is dead upon mine and my master's false accusation.
And, briefly, I desire nothing but the reward of a villain.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Prince, I won't wait for my trial: listen to my story, and let the count kill me now. I tricked your own eyes. These stupid fools have uncovered what you in all your wisdom could not. They heard me confess to Conrade how Don John, your brother, prompted me to slander Hero - how you came to the orchard and saw me making sexual advances toward Margaret, who was disguised as Hero; how you disgraced Hero when you should have married her. They've recorded my crimes, and I would rather die than have to retell this shameful story. The lady has died because of the false accusations of me and my master. I desire nothing now but a criminal's punishment.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
(to CLAUDIO) Runs not this speech like iron through your
(to
)
blood?
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
(to CLAUDIO) Doesn't this make your blood run cold?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
His words are like poison to me.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
(to BORACHIO) But did my brother set thee on to this?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
(to BORACHIO) But did my brother prompt you to do all this?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Yes, and paid me well for doing it.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
He is composed and framed of treachery,
And fled he is upon this villainy.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
He is made of treachery, and has run away to avoid his crimes.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I loved it first.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Sweet Hero; when I imagine you now, you seem as beautiful as you did when I first loved you.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Come, bring away the plaintiffs. By this time our sexton
hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. And,
masters, do not forget to specify, when time and place shall
serve, that I am an ass.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
Come, take away the
plaintiffs. By now the sexton will have reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. (to CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) And, gentlemen, please do not forget to specify, whenever it is convenient, that I am an ass.
plaintiffs



(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
VERGES
Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton
too.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES
Here comes Master Signior Leonato with the sexton.

paragraphs.original:
Enter LEONATO andANTONIO, with the SEXTON
LEONATO
ANTONIO
SEXTON
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO and ANTONIO enter with the SEXTON.
LEONATO
ANTONIO
SEXTON

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes,
That, when I note another man like him,
I may avoid him. Which of these is he?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Which one of them did it? Let me see what he looks like, so when I see another man who resembles him, I'll know to avoid him. Which one is it?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
If you would know your wronger, look on me.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
If you want to see your deceiver, then look at me.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed
Mine innocent child?
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Are you the slave who, with your slanderous words, killed my innocent child?

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
Yea, even I alone.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
Yes, I am the one.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.
Here stand a pair of honorable men - 
A third is fled - that had a hand in it. - 
I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death.
Record it with your high and worthy deeds.
'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
No, villain, but you didn't work alone. (indicating CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) For here are two noblemen  - the third has run away - who helped you. (to CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) Thank you, gentlemen, for my daughter's death. Make a note of it on your long lists of righteous and worthy deeds. It was very brave of you.
(indicating
and
)
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself.
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin. Yet sinned I not
But in mistaking.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I don't know how to ask you for forgiveness, but I have to say something. Choose your revenge. Punish me through any means you can devise, though I sinned by mistake.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
By my soul, nor I,
And yet to satisfy this good old man
I would bend under any heavy weight
That he'll enjoin me to.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
Me too - but to satisfy this good old man, I too will bear any punishment he gives me.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I cannot bid you bid my daughter live - 
That were impossible - but, I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here
How innocent she died. And if your love
Can labor ought in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb
And sing it to her bones. Sing it tonight.
Tomorrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son-in-law,
Be yet my nephew. My brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that's dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us.
Give her the right you should have given her cousin,
And so dies my revenge.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I can't ask you to make my daughter live - that's impossible - but I beg you both to tell the people of Messina that she was innocent when she died. And if your love can produce something from its sadness, write a poem for her; hang it on her grave and sing it to her bones. Sing it tonight. Then come to my house tomorrow morning, and since you couldn't be my son-in-law, be my nephew instead. My brother has a daughter who looks exactly like Hero; this girl is heir to both our estates. Marry her as you should have married her cousin, and I will let my revenge die.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
O noble sir!
Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
I do embrace your offer; and dispose
For henceforth of poor Claudio.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Oh, noble sir! Your overwhelming kindness makes me weep. I willingly accept your offer and put my future in your hands.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Tomorrow then I will expect your coming.
Tonight I take my leave. This naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was packed in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I will see you tomorrow, then. Now I have to leave. This wicked man will be brought face to face with Margaret, who I believe was hired by Don John to take part in this plot.

paragraphs.original:
BORACHIO
No, by my soul, she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous
In any thing that I do know by her.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO
No, she wasn't, and she didn't know anything about it. She has always been honest and good.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
(to LEONATO) Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under
(to
)
white and black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me
ass. I beseech you, let it be remembered in his punishment.
And also the watch heard them talk of one Deformed. They
say he wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it and
borrows money in God's name, the which he hath used so
long and never paid that now men grow hard-hearted and
will lend nothing for God's sake. Pray you, examine him
upon that point.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
(to LEONATO) Also, sir, this hasn't been put down in writing, but I should let you know that this
plaintiff here, the criminal, did in fact call me an ass. Please remember that when you're punishing him. Plus, the watchmen heard the criminals talking about some man named
Deformed. They say that he has an earring made out of a key, with a lock hanging from it. Apparently, he borrows money from people in the name of God and then never pays it back, which angers everyone so much that they now refuse to fund anything in the name of God. Make sure you ask him about this.
(to
)
plaintiff



Deformed

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Thank you for all your efforts.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent
youth, and I praise God for you.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
You speak like a very thankful and respectful boy, and may God bless you.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
(giving him money) There's for thy pains.
(giving him money)
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
(giving DOGBERRY money) This is for your trouble.
(giving
money)

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
God save the foundation!
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
God save the charitable organization!

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
Go, you're relieved of your duty. Thank you.

paragraphs.original:
DOGBERRY
I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech
your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.
God keep your Worship! I wish your Worship well. God
restore you to health! I humbly give you leave to depart, and
if a merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it! - 
Come, neighbor.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY
I leave a slimy bastard with you, your Worship, for you to punish and make an example of. God bless your Worship! I wish you well. I hope that God restores you to health. I will humbly let you go now, God
prohibiting we will meet again in the future. - Come on, man.
prohibiting

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt DOGBERRY andVERGES
DOGBERRY
VERGES
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY and VERGES exit.
DOGBERRY
VERGES

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
Until tomorrow morning, lords, farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
I'll see you tomorrow morning, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONIO
Farewell, my lords. We look for you tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONIO
Goodbye, gentlemen. We'll see you tomorrow.

paragraphs.original:
DON PEDRO
We will not fail.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO
We'll be there.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Tonight I'll mourn with Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
I will mourn Hero tonight.

paragraphs.original:
LEONATO
(to the Watch)
(to the Watch)
Bring you these fellows on. - We'll talk with Margaret,
How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO
(to the watchmen) Bring these criminals with us. We'll go talk to Margaret, to see how she got involved with this worthless man.
(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter BENEDICK andMARGARET
BENEDICK
MARGARET
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK andMARGARET enter.
BENEDICK
MARGARET

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my
hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Please Margaret, help me write this poem for Beatrice.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
Afterward, will you write a sonnet for me, praising my beauty?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shall come
over it, for in most comely truth thou deservest it.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I'll write you such a glorious sonnet, Margaret, that no man will ever be able to come over it. You certainly deserve it.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
To have no man come over me! Why, shall I always keep
below stairs?
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
No man will come
over me! What a life that would be!
over me

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound's mouth; it catches.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Your wit is as quick as a greyhound's jaws - it catches whatever it goes after.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
And yours as blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit but hurt
not.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
And your wit is as blunt as a practice sword, with its dull tip; it hits people but doesn't hurt them.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman. And
so, I pray thee, call Beatrice. I give thee the bucklers.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
It's just that my wit is very gentlemanly, Margaret, and refuses to hurt a woman. Now please, tell Beatrice to come out. I admit defeat; I give you the
bucklers.
bucklers

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our own.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
No, you should give a woman your sword - we have our own
bucklers!
bucklers

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with
a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for maids.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Watch out, though, Margaret - virgins shouldn't be brandishing their bucklers around.

paragraphs.original:
MARGARET
Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET
I'll go get Beatrice for you, who can walk here by herself - she has legs.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
And therefore will come.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
So that means she'll come.

paragraphs.original:
Exit MARGARET
MARGARET
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET exits.
MARGARET

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
The god of love,
The god of love
That sits above,
That sits above
And knows me, and knows me,
And knows me, and knows me
How pitiful I deserve - 
How pitiful I deserve
I mean in singing. But in loving, Leander the good swimmer, Troilus the first employer of panders, and a whole bookful of these quondam carpetmongers, whose names yet run smoothly in the even road of a blank verse, why, they were never so truly turned over and over as my poor self in love. Marry, I cannot show it in rhyme. I have tried. I can find out no rhyme to "lady" but "baby" - an innocent rhyme; for "scorn," "horn" - a hard rhyme; for, "school," "fool" - a babbling rhyme; very ominous endings. No, I was not born under a rhyming planet, nor I cannot woo in festival terms.
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
The god of love
The god of love
He sits in heaven above
He sits in heaven above
And he knows me, he knows me
And he knows me, he knows me
He knows how much pity I deserve - 
He knows how much pity I deserve - 
I'm really a pitiful singer. But as a lover, well, that's another story. Take
Leander, Troilus, or an entire book's worth of those legendary lover–boys, whose names sound so smooth and nice in a line of verse - not one of them has been driven as crazy by love as I have been. But I can't prove it in a poem. I have tried. I can't think of any rhyme for "lady" but "baby," which is a childish rhyme. The only rhyme for "scorn" I can come up with is
"horn" - a bit off for a love poem. Nothing rhymes with "school" but "fool," and that's a ridiculous jingle. These are all very unpromising line endings. No, I wasn't destined to be a poet, and I can't woo a lady with pretty words.
Leander, Troilus



"horn"

paragraphs.original:
Enter BEATRICE
BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE enters.
BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?
paragraphs.translated: Beatrice, have you come because I called for you?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Yea, Signior, and depart when you bid me.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Yes, sir, and I'll leave when you ask me to.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Oh , stay but till then!
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Oh, well, stay till then!

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
"Then" is spoken. Fare you well now. And yet, ere I go, let
me go with that I came, which is, with knowing what hath
passed between you and Claudio.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
There - you said "then." So I'll leave now. But before I go, let me get what I came for. What happened between you and Claudio?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss thee.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I spoke angry, foul words to him, and with that I will kiss you.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul
breath, and foul breath is noisome. Therefore I will depart
unkissed.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
If you had foul words in your mouth, then your breath must be foul, and foul breath is nauseating. Thus, I'll leave without being kissed.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so
forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio
undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear
from him, or I will subscribe him a coward. And I pray thee
now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall
in love with me?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Your wit is so forceful, it frightens the very meaning out of your words. But I will tell you this very plainly: I have challenged Claudio, and either he'll accept the challenge or admit he's a coward. Now, tell me - which of my bad qualities did you fall in love with first?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
For them all together, which maintained so politic a state of
evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle
with them. But for which of my good parts did you first
suffer love for me?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
With all of them at once: they work together to create such an entirely evil person that no good ever manages to enter the mix. But tell me - which of my good qualities first made you suffer love for me?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Suffer love! A good epithet! I do suffer love indeed, for I
love thee against my will.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Suffer love! That's a good way of putting it. I do suffer love, because I love you against my will.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
In spite of your heart, I think. Alas, poor heart, if you spite
it for my sake, I will spite it for yours, for I will never love
that which my riend hates.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
You love me in spite of your heart, I think. If you spite your heart for my sake, then I will spite it for yours. I will never love the thing my friend hates.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
You and I are too wise to woo each other peacefully.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
It appears not in this confession. There's not one wise man
among twenty that will praise himself.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
It's said that no truly wise man will praise himself. If you say that you are wise, it's likely you're not.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived in the lime of
good neighbors. If a man do not erect in this age his own
tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than
the bell rings and the widow weeps.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
That's an old proverb, Beatrice, from the time when neighbors praised each other. In this day and age, if a man doesn't erect his own monument before he dies, he won't be remembered past the funeral bell's ringing and his widow's crying.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
And how long is that, think you?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Exactly how long is that, do you think?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Question: why, an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum.
Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm,
his conscience, find no impediment to the contrary, to be
the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much
for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is
praiseworthy. An now tell me, how doth your cousin?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
About an hour for the ringing and fifteen minutes for the crying. That's why it's better for wise men to trumpet their own virtues, like I do. That's why I praise myself, who - if I do say so myself - is quite praiseworthy. But tell me, how is your cousin?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Very ill.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
She's very sick.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
And how do you?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
And how are you?

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Very ill, too.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
I'm very sick, too.

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
Serve God, love me, and mend. There will I leave you too,
for here comes one in haste.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
Have faith, love me, and you will get better. And that's where I'll end, because someone is hurrying this way.

paragraphs.original:
Enter URSULA
URSULA
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA enters.
URSULA

paragraphs.original:
URSULA
Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder's old coil at
home. It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely
accused, the Prince and Claudio mightily abused, and Don
John is the author of all, who is fled and gone. Will you
come presently?
paragraphs.translated:
URSULA
Madam, you have to go to your uncle's. There's a huge racket going on there. It's been proven that Lady Hero is innocent, that the Prince and Claudio have been utterly deceived, and that Don John - who has run away - is the source of all the trouble. Will you come immediately?

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
BEATRICE
Will you go hear this news, Signior?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE
Will you come with me to hear this news, sir?

paragraphs.original:
BENEDICK
I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy
eyes - and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncle's.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK
I will live in your heart, die in your lap, and be buried in your eyes - and, what's more, I will go with you to your uncle's.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, three or four LORDS with tapers, and musicians
DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO
LORDS
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDROand CLAUDIO enter with three or four LORDS carrying candles, and musicians.
DON PEDRO
CLAUDIO
LORDS

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Is this the monument of Leonato?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Is this the family tomb of Leonato?

paragraphs.original:
FIRST LORD
It is, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST LORD
It is, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
(reading an epitaph)
(reading an epitaph)
Done to death by slanderous tongues
Was the Hero that here lies.
Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies.
So the life that died with shame
Lives in death with glorious fame.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
(reading an epitaph)
(reading an epitaph)
Here lies Hero,
The heroic maiden killed by slanderous words.
To repay her for her troubles, Death
Gives her undying fame.
So the life that died with shame
Lives on with fame.

paragraphs.original: Hangs the scroll
paragraphs.translated: (he hangs the scroll)

paragraphs.original:
Hang thou there upon the tomb,
Praising her when I am dumb.
Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.
(Song)
(Song)

Pardon, goddess of the night
Those that slew thy virgin knight,
Those that slew thy virgin knight
For the which with songs of woe
For the which with songs of woe
Round about her tomb they go.
Round about her tomb they go
Midnight, assist our moan.
Midnight, assist our moan
Help us to sigh and groan
Help us to sigh and groan
Heavily, heavily.
Heavily, heavily
Graves, yawn and yield your dead,
Graves, yawn and yield your dead
Till death be utterèd,
Till death be utterèd
Heavily, heavily.

paragraphs.translated:
This epitaph will hang here forever,
Continuing to praise Hero after I die.
Now start the music, and sing the solemn hymn.
(singing)
(singing)
Please pardon, goddess of the night,
Please pardon, goddess of the night
The men who killed your
virgin knight.
The men who killed your
virgin knight



These men now walk around her tomb,
These men now walk around her tomb
Singing songs of woe.
Singing songs of woe
Oh, midnight, join our moaning
Oh, midnight, join our moaning
Help us with our sighs and groaning
Help us with our sighs and groaning
Heavily, heavily.

Graves, open up and release your corpses
